scenes.location: BRANCH RICKEY'S OFFICE MONTAGUE ST, BROOKLYN D
characters: B172 DIXIE WALKER AT BAT B172
MAKES HIS WAY UP THE TUNNEL. 107
YOU CAN WIPE YOUR ASSES WITH IT
THE PLAYERS LINED UP FOR THE NATIONAL ANTHEM 110

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinds closed. Dust motes in the air. A large GOLDFISH TA bubbles. BRANCH RICKEY at his desk. Two photos on the wal Abe Lincoln & Leo Durocher. CHALKBOARDS covered with OF NAMES, every player in the Dodger organization. CLYDE SUKEFORTH and HAROLD PARROTT sit across from Rickey who stares at them. Sukeforth stares back. Parrott nervou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I have a plan... As of now, only the Board of Directors and my family know. Sukeforth and Parrott exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plan's always good, Mr. Rickey. And you always got one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife says I'm too old, That my health isn't up to it. My son says that every one in baseball will be against me. But I'm going to do it. Parrott looks to Sukeforth who keeps his eyes on Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what, Mr. Rickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to bring a Negro ballplayer to the Brooklyn Dodgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, have you lost your mind? Imagine the abuse you'll take from the newspapers alone. Never mind how it'll play on Flatbush. Please, Mr. Rickey. Rickey looks dismissively at Parrott, over to Sukeforth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no law against it, Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a code. Break a law and get away with it, some people think you're smart. Break an unwritten law though, you'll be an outcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it. New York is full of Negro baseball fans; every dollar is green. I don't know who he is, or where he is, but he's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big Birmingham Black Barons CATCHER behind the plate Kansas City Monarchs JOHN SCOTT stands at bat. The catche attention on the RUNNER DANCING off first. Stomping a foo feinting, hard to see clearly in the glare of the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you learn to move like that, runner?! At dime a dance night?! Stay quiet! INSERT: Birmingham, Alabama. April 8, 1945.  On the first pitch the runner takes off. The catcher fire second. See it from his POV as the runner slides in âSA A foot on the bag, the runner dusts off, heckles the catc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the best you got?! Huh?! I'm going to steal nine, ten bases today! You better start counting! The catcher frowns. Standing, we see he is a big, big man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your shortstop from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a mouth on him. Shaking his head, the catcher gets back in his crouch, signals the PITCHER. On the wind-up, the Runner is off again. The catcher fires to THIRD: âSafe!â

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a rag arm, catcher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steal home! You'll find out what kind of arm I got!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm coming! The Catcher looks over at Scott who chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well California here he goes, if he comes down here. The Catcher gets back down in his squat. Signals the pitcher: fastball. Scott digs in, ready. The runner danci off third. Here comes the wind-up... The Runner takes off even as the pitcher fires it in. The Birmingham Catcher receives it. As the Runner slides -- The Catcher intentionally drives his glove, the ball and hands into the runner's face -- WHALLOP! Sound drops as we're knocked flat senseless along with the runner. ON HIM now as he tries to push himself up from the dirt. close look at JACK ROOSEVELT ROBINSON. A born battler, he shakes out the cobwebs, finally lurches to his feet, look the UMPIRE. He never heard the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I? The umpire passes one hand over the other: Safe. Jack loo over at the catcher, gives him a pointed look as he goes The catcher shoves him in the back. Jack turns, shoves ba As the two men wrestles each other to the ground --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey and Sukeforth going through stacks of FILES on the desk. A black ballplayer's picture is clipped to each. As Rickey reviews one, Sukeforth tries to hand him another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh Gibson. Oh boy can he hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Rickey won't take the file; the answer is no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Roy Campanella. Sukeforth holds it out; Rickey won't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heck of a player. But too sweet, they'll eat him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up file)  Satchel Paige then. Parrott enters carrying an armful of files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too old. We need a man with a future not a past.  (holds up his own

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Jack Roosevelt Robinson.  As Parrott sets them on the desk, they start to slide off spilling to the floor. Helpless to stem the tide, Parrott looks down, surrounded by black faces...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips through file) A four sport college man, out of UCLA. That means he's played with white boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six years old, now with the Kansas City Monarchs. Batting over 350 even as we speak. 350! And he  was a commissioned army officer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was court-martialed. A trouble maker. He argues with umpires. A quick temper is his reputation. Rickey is obviously keen on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he court-martialed for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For refusing to sit in the back of  a military bus.  (checks the file)  Ft. Hood, Texas. The driver asked  him to move back. The MPs had to  take him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see he resents segregation. If  he were white, we'd call it spirit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were white, sir, we wouldn't  be looking for him. Rickey ends the debate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robinson's a Methodist. I'm a  Methodist. God's a Methodist. We  can't go wrong. Find him. Bring him  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLOODHOUND watches as a BUS pulls into a SERVICE STATIO the tires RING the bell hose. A million miles easy on thi road rumbler. The BANNER reads: KC Monarchs. Insert: Interstate 24, Missouri - August 24, 1945. The DRIVER steps off. The fellas follow, getting off to stretch their legs. Hot and tired. A WHITE ATTENDANT saunters out. The driver steps over to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill her up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The attendant starts unscrewing caps on two 50-GALLON TAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you all headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicago. As the attendant shoves down a pump, starts filling, Jack steps off. He spots and heads for a restroom. White Men Only lettered on the door. The attendant roused as he see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Where you going, boy!?

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 6.
dialogues.text: Everyone looking over as Jack stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, boy, c'mon. You know you can't go in there. Jack does a slow burn, then suddenly strides toward the attendant. The air rife with tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that hose out of the tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it out. We'll get our ninety- nine gallons of gas someplace else. The attendant blinks. He takes a look from Jack to up and down the deserted highway. No business in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, use it. But don't stay in there too long. Jack heads back. The Driver, the players, a bit stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack splashes water on his face, rips a paper towels from dispenser, pats his face dry. He balls the wad up, squeez it in his fist before firing it into the trash. He consid his reflection in the mirror. As he regards himself, we h the SERVICE BELL ring outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car has pulled up. The driver talks to several players. They look over as Jack exits. The driver is Clyde Sukefor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Jackie Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinds closed. Jack sits across the desk from Rickey. Sukeforth sits a little further back. Rickey is staring a Jack. Bushy eyebrows flared, light gleams off his glasses INSERT: August 28, 1945. Brooklyn.  Jack doesn't know what to do, looks to Sukeforth. Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man needs a family relying on him. It insures he'll behave responsibly. Do you have a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so? Jack looks to Sukeforth who smiles placidly. Back to Rick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make much money. Between the army and now baseball I've been away a lot. And Rae, Rachel, she wants to finish school. Considering all that, I say I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love her? Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry her. What? Rickey stands, walks to a window. Jack looks at Sukeforth who raises a hand as if to say: Give it a chanc

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baseball's a hard life; a man needs a good woman by his side. You don't want the only person waiting for you at home to be a catcher. Sukeforth chuckles at that. Rickey fingers open a slat on the blind and peers out. Jack looks hard at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Sukeforth here said you were starting a new Negro League. That doesn't make sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: MR. RICKEY
dialogues.text: It doesn't, huh? Are you calling us liars, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about, Mr. Rickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about baseball. Rickey opens the shade. Sunlight floods in. Rickey follow it to the chalkboard, to the list of players under Montre

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see you starting in the spring with our affiliate in Montreal. If you make it there, we'll try you down here with the Dodgers. The white Brooklyn Dodgers. Jack looks to Sukeforth who nods: Yes, you heard right.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll pay you $600 a month and a $3,500 bonus when you sign the contract. Is that agreeable? Believe it or not that's a lot of money to Jack on this d in time. This is all becoming a bit overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one condition. I have a pile of scouting reports. I know you can hit behind the runner, that you can read a pitch. The question is can you control your temper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My temper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes your temper! Are you deaf?!  Rickey furious, the avuncular old man gone. Jack sits the fists now balled. Rickey to Sukeforth like he's not there

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He looks proud. Willful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll need to be. Rickey looks back to Jack who is as angry as he is confus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to win! I want ballplayers who can win! Are you one of them?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black man in white baseball. Imagine the reaction. The vitriol. Rickey strides forward, gets in his face.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Dodgers check into a hotel. A decent good hotel. You're worn out from the road and some clerk won't give you the pen to sign in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got no room, boy, not even down in the coal bin where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 10.
dialogues.text: Jack looks like he wants to tear Rickey apart.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The team stops at a restaurant. The waiter won't take your order. (adopts a new voice) Didn't you see the sign on the door? No animals allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do then? Fight him? Ruin all my plans? Answer me, you black sonofabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a ballplayer who doesn't have the guts to fight back? Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want one who has the guts not to fight back! There are people who will not like this. They will do anything to get you to react. If you echo a curse with a curse, they will only hear yours. Follow a blow with a blow and they will say a Negro lost his temper; that the Negro does not belong. Your enemy will be out in force, but you can not meet him on his own low ground. We win with hitting, running and fielding, nothing else. We win if the world is convinced of two things: that you are a fine gentlemen and a great ballplayer. Like our Savior, you must have the guts to turn the other cheek. Jack considers Rickey. Rickey looks worn out.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you do it? Jack poised at what will be his Rubicon. He crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey, you give me a uniform, you give me a number on my back, and I'll give you the guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone RINGS on a table. RACHEL ISUM steps in, 23, possessed of style that you can only be graced with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack in a PHONE BOOTH, the lobby busy beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae, I'm in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooklyn? For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to say on the phone. In fact, I'm not supposed to tell anyone. She can hear the tingle in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, Rae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? You're supposed  to be playing in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been tested you and me. Our  loyalty, our faith. We've done  everything the right way. Me  trying to make money. You  finishing school. Separated by the  war, now by baseball. We don't owe  the world a thing. Only each other.  She's actually getting a little scared now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, what are you talking about? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brooklyn Dodgers just signed me to play ball up in Montreal. It might lead to bigger things. To something wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it mean? For you and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae. Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I don't think we can get married in a phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: A INT. HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Jack rounds a corner in a TUXEDO, the bow tie undone. Rac follows in her WEDDING GOWN. They look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my mom look happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They reach the door. Jack gets out a key to unlock it.  Rachel looks nervous, steps back across the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my gram look happy?  Swinging the door open, he looks at her. The air charged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looked happy. I've never seen so many people looking happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Jack Robinson look happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I can't make you happy? He steps over, aware of her shyness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. You already do. It's  you and me, Rae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until the wheels fall off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can wait one more night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming, Mrs. Robinson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kisses him back)  I'd follow you anywhere, Mr.  Robinson.  He picks her up, carries her over the threshold. As the d clicks shut behind them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shades closed; we're scheming again. WENDELL SMITH si across from Rickey who stares back intently. Bespectacled 32, Smith covers baseball for the Pittsburgh Courier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the best shortstop you ever saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit Tavener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit Tavener? And you call yourself a sports writer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, a sentimental one. I'm from Detroit. He was the Tiger shortstop when I was a boy. How about you? Who's your best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Honus Wagner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wagner is number two. And Rabbit Tavener would not break my top 25. Where do you suppose Jackie Robinson will end up on that list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't break it. He doesn't have a shortstop's arm. Robinson belongs on second base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then, where would he rate at second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he was playing now he'd be the best second baseman in the majors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High praise. He'll have to be the best in the minor leagues first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying, Mr. Rickey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying it's going to be a very interesting spring training. A lot of players are coming back from the war and with gas rationing over, we can train down in Florida again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daytona Beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're aware in the past six months a black boy was lynched in Madison, Florida and a black man down in Live Oaks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those towns may as well be a million miles from Daytona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live Oaks is 150 actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to the Daytona mayor. He assures me there'll be no trouble. But Rickey doesn't sound so sure. They consider each othe

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Smith, are you a Communist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Democrat. Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a business proposition. What's your salary at the Courier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty dollars a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will pay you an additional fifty dollars a week plus expenses if you will attend spring training with Jackie Robinson. You will watch over him, help him to avoid the harm that could come if he were to do or say anything out of turn. You will act as his chauffeur, you will secure accommodations for him wherever the team may be, help him find restaurants, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in it for me? Besides the fifty dollars and a whole lot of aggravation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unprecedented access for any reportage you feel appropriate. What do you say, Mr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say yes, sir. If a Negro is good enough to stop a Nazi bullet in France; he's good enough to stop a line drive at Yankee Stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebbets Field actually, but yes, I agree. The world is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over 500 guests: journalists, players and politicians all listen politely as a SPEECH drones to an end. INSERT: New York City. 23rd Annual Baseball Writer's Association Dinner February 3, 1946.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As our former President Herbert Hoover remarked in his tribute to our national pastime: âThe rigid voluntary rules of right and wrong, as applied in baseball, are second only to religion in strengthening the morals of the American people.' Polite applause as the speaker steps off. The clapping mo enthusiastic as the lights dim on all but an impromptu se plantation house columns. Hoots as a BUTLER appears weari satin knee breeches and a MONTREAL ROYALS jersey. He hold ring like a lawn jockey, a WHITE MAN in BLACK FACE. The laughs get louder as he peers out with exaggerated wide e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lordy, lordy, it's looking like da massa will be late dis ebning. As the LAUGHS from the audience subside, a sportswriter dressed as a COLONEL enters from stage right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie! Robbie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yassuh, Massa Kunl. Here Ah is. Huge LAUGHS as he struts and dances his way over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, you woolly headed rascal. How long yo' been in the family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebber since Massa Rickey done bots me from da Kansas City Monarchs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to audience) Rickey that no good carpetbagger! What could he be thinking! Huge LAUGHS from that one. Two people enjoying it we'll recognize later as HERB PENNOCK and BOB COOKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah came near bein' killed last night, Kunl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, Jackie boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah was comin' up a dark street and three men was behind me. And they tried to do me with a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, suh. Ah recognized one of dem. Ah'm gonna hab him arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you said it was dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was. But I know he played for the Philadelphia Baseball Club. On account of he struck at me three times and never hit me once. That brings the house down. Check out their laughing face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gleaming American Airlines DC-3 angled up on the tarmac PASSENGERS climb the portable stairs and disappear inside INSERT: February 28, 1946. Burbank, California

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Rachel are being seen off by FRIENDS from the wedding and his mother MALLIE. Jack is in a natty suit wi Rachel in a beautiful coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knock the cover off that ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Mama. Mallie hugs Jack and then kisses Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look after each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will. She reaches in her bag, brings out a cardboard SHOEBOX; i ever so slightly greasy at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this. It's chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have food on the plane, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know what might happen. I don't want you getting there starving and too weak to hit. Rachel gives Jack a subtle but emphatic look: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack escorts Rachel to the plane, the shoebox in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't tell her no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she means well; I just don't want to be seen eating chicken out of a box like some country bumpkin. Jack runs his hand over her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's going to mistake you for a bumpkin in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they'll know I belong on that plane or wherever I happen to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Descending toward a runway. Landing gear coming down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN exits the lady's room, passing a SIGN: White Only REVERSE to show Rachel looking at it like she's been slap Jack joins Rae from the TICKET COUNTER, with the chicken INSERT: New Orleans Lakefront Airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight to Pensacola leaves in an hour... You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just never seen one before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (follows her look) We're not in Pasadena anymore. A sudden momentum carries her forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey... Rae -- He takes a step after her, stops as she disappears inside Jack unsure what to do. He looks around. Looks back. He  doesn't need this right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black BUSBOY reacts as a bickering Jack and Rachel ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised Mr. Rickey we'd stay out  of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you promise him we wouldn't go  to the bathroom? You've done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a toilet. You'd think  the commodes were made of gold.  The busboy watches as Jack and Rachel slide into a booth. Jack reaches for a MENU, here comes the COOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks can't sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's white only. Jack looking to Rachel; it's equanimity time. Not easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sell you some sandwiches. But you gotta take âem to go. Jack looks to the busboy, back to the cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You hang onto those. Mastering himself, Jack slides out. Drilling the cook wit look, he offers his hand to Rachel as she slides out as w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from on high. Jack and Rachel, sitting on a bench, t little figures as passengers move along the concourse. Th sit a bit apart from each other, the world a wedge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMOKE PINWHEELS as the wheels of a BOEING 247 touch down. INSERT: Pensacola, Florida. Later that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Rachel worn out among eight other passengers. As the door is opened, FOUR of the eight get up and disembar After a beat, FOUR NEW PASSENGERS board and take their se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a hop to Daytona now. As Rachel nods, an AIRLINE EMPLOYEE boards, MISS BISHOP. makes her way over. She spots who she's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Robinson? Come with me. She starts away without explaining, looks back at them a impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now. Both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shoe box sitting on the counter, Jack in mid discussi with Miss Bishop. Rachel just behind Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to lighten the plane. There's some bad weather east of here. A heavy plane's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her you're with the Dodgers.  Jack would rather not play that card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the next flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. But it's booked. So someone'll have to cancel. Jack and Rachel unaware as a WHITE COUPLE are ushered out door and onto the tarmac behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm with the Brooklyn Dodger organization. I've got to get down to Daytona. I'm supposed to report to spring training in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best to get you down there by tomorrow afternoon, but it might be the day after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows her gaze to where the white couple get on the plane they got off. Jack wheels on Miss Bishop, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave away our seats! Get us back on that plane! Miss Bishop picks up a PHONE, holds it in Jack's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to call the Sheriff? Or should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closed. A line of EMPTY BUSES; the BANNER on one: Daytona Beach. Across from it Rachel sits at one end of a BENCH, fur pulled around her. Jack at the other, staring off int the night. Finally, he reaches down, picks up the shoebox He pulls out a DRUMSTICK, considers it, then takes a bite

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama knew... He holds it out to Rachel. She slides over, takes it, tak a bite as well, smiles at him. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEO DUROCHER hitting fungoes. One after the next. PEE WEE REESE and EDDIE STANKY both settle under the same ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it! I got it! I got it! I got it! They both back off at the last second and it drops to the ground between them. Durocher chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what spring training's for, boys! Sort out our differences! He hits another. This time to the outfield where veteran DIXIE WALKER gives chase, finally gives up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Dixie, get after it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm old!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna squeeze one more year out of that worn out body of yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could, skipper, my wife would sure appreciate it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping the women happy! That's what it's all about!

dialogues.speaker: A EXT./INT. CONVERTIBLE
dialogues.text: Rickey drives a dirt road through the training field sing âTwo Sleepy Peopleâ along with the radio: Passing BRO DODGERS, MONTREAL ROYALS & ST. PAUL SAINTS on either Durocher hits another as Rickey pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are they looking, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty, Mr. Rickey. But we'll get âem oiled up and ready in no time. You find your lost sheep yet? Troubled, Rickey shakes his head âno'. As he does, Haro Parrot hurries over. He's the Dodgers travelling secretar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie Robinson's on a bus leaving Pensacola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus? Harold, how in blazes did he end up on a bus?! BOB BRAGAN, in his catching gear, passing by with pitcher RALPH BRANCA and KIRBY HIGBE. Higbe asides to Bragan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't they just put him on a  watermelon truck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing, Branca, but we ain't just two pretty faces either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell Smith stands waiting as a BUS pulls in. The big air brakes hiss. The doors open and the PASSENGER disembark. First a DOZEN WHITE FACES, then a DOZEN BLACK. Last but not least, Rachel and Jack. They look exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie Robinson... Mr. Rickey sent me to meet you. Wendell Smith. Pittsburgh Courier. I'm going to be your Boswell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your chronicler, your advance man. Hell, even your chauffeur. (tips his hat) Mrs. Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you two look wiped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a car? Get us out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Smith carry the luggage. Smith's excited being  around Jack even if he is grumpy. As Smith unlocks the  Buick, Rachel considers a segregated pair of water founta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been down South before, Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time. We have our problems in Pasadena, but not like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey says we follow the law. If Jim Crow and the state of Florida say Negroes do this and that, then we do this and that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life's changing right in front of me. Who I am, who I think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black neighborhood. The Buick stops at a nice looking hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Duff Harris live here. He gets out the black vote, does a lot of good for colored folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey set it up himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can't put the Robinsons in the hotels, they should stay some- place that represents something. Jack and Rachel exchange a look, the place seems nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooklyn plays downtown; Montreal a  few blocks from here. You'll stay with the Harrises except for a few  days at the end of the week. The  whole Dodger organization is going to Sanford, about 45 minute away.  You'll stay here though, Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the other wives staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no other wives. You're the only one Mr. Rickey allowed to spring training. As the HARRISES step out on the porch, wave hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. HARRIS leads Jack and Rachel up the stairs to a door the top. Mrs. Harris opens it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HARRIS
dialogues.text: I call this the love nest. I hope you like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. Thank you. As Jack enters, Mrs. Harris starts back down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HARRIS
dialogues.text: Dinner's at five. Rachel enters, closes the door behind her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And accidentally knocks Jack onto the bed. She lands o top of him. The room is impossibly small. It barely holds their luggage and the BED they're on. As they look around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it. The love nest. She kisses him. He's starting to like it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remind me dinner's at five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try to remember... As the kisses become more urgent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith pulls up alongside the team buses, looks across at who is just a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day of Spring Training.  My Pittsburgh Courier readers need  to know how it feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not exactly a headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jack, right now it's just me  asking you. But you get on that  field and it's going to be the New  York Times and the Sporting News.  You should think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they ask something, I'll answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, but you know when you're  at the plate, you want to feel like  you see the pitch come in slow?  Well, you want to see the questions  come in slow, too.  Jack just looks at him. Gets out. Smith sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PLAYERS (Brooklyn, St. Paul & Montreal) warm up, p Rickey sits on the bench, angry as he reads a NEWSPAPER. Harold Parrott hurries over, something urgent on his mind Rickey on a rant; Parrott can't get a word in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this, Harold. Whenever I hear a white man - yours truly - broadcasting what a Moses he is to the Negro race, then I know the latter needs a bodyguard. (Parrott tries to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is those of the carpetbagger stripe of the white race - me again - who under the guise of helping, in truth are using the Negro for their own selfish interest, thereby retarding the race! Parrott tries to interrupt again, but Rickey is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minor league commissioner of baseball said that! I pay part of his salary! You wouldn't stab me in the back like this, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here, Mr. Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say so?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack crossing toward them in his Montreal Monarchs unifor carrying a glove and a bat. 200 white players clocking hi He's surrounded by REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS. It's the for most of the batting and fielding and chatter among th Dodgers, Royals and Saints to come to a stop. Higbe forgets Bragan is throwing him a ball. It clocks hi in the chest. Reese and Stanky passing a medicine ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a wild guess. Flash bulbs go off in Jack's face. Questions like punches Shouts of âJackie' and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, do you think you can make it with these white boys? Jack looks off to where Smith watches, back to the report See the questions slow. He answers with measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I had no problem with white men in the service or at UCLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you do if one of these pitchers throws at your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks a beat)  I'll duck. That gets some laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, what's your natural position?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been playing shortstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you after Pee Wee Reese's job?

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 27A.
dialogues.text: Jack looks over to where Reese watches with Stanky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese plays for Brooklyn. I'm  worried about making Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this about politics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about getting paid. Jack doing beautifully.  Smith breathes a sigh of relief...

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER CLAY HOPPER
dialogues.text: In a Montreal uniform, Hopper's too old to be a ballplaye He stands with Dixie Walker the Dodger right fielder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when Mr. Rickey picks one, he sure picks a black one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fine with me, so long as you keep him up in Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the old man to save him. They watch as Rickey pulls Jack from the press. He leads Jack directly toward Hopper. As Walker excuses himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Hop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, I'd like you to meet Jackie Robinson. Jackie, Clay Hopper, manager of the Montreal Royals. Hopper shakes his hand as they exchange greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't doing much today. Just throwing the ball around and hitting a few. Why don't you toss a few with those fellas over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jorgensen! A kid in a Montreal uniform looks over. SPIDER JORGENSEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet Jackie Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of the day. Buses leave by team, the Dodgers and farm clubs. White faces look down as they pass a tired Ja who walks through the lot toward Wendell Smith and his Bu Higbe and Bragan call out from the door of the Dodger bus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rook! Did you hear about the redneck shortstop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought the last two words of the National Anthem were Play Ball! Jack forces a smile, but the joke comes off a bit harsh. they seem like they're laughing at him as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the shortstop making all the errors, tried to kill himself by jumping out on the highway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus just missed him. Drove right between his legs! As the bus passes by, Jack sees the impassive faces of Di Walker, Reiser, Stanky, Pee Wee Reese and finally 20-year Branca. Branca smiles, offers an awkward little wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between his legs, good one. He  must've read a joke book. If he  can read.  Jack just gets in the car. Smith sighs, drum rolls the ho of the Buick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Wendell, how are you...? Well,  looks like I got a long drive to  Sanford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. BROCK comes out the screen door carrying a tray of ta drinks. He sets them on a table, watches and waits as Smi and Jack get out of the Buick, start up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: Jackie, I'm Ray Brock. Welcome to Sanford Florida! The day belongs to decent minded people. They shake hands. Brock looks to Smith, obviously knows h

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: Wendell, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's inside cooking. You know what she asked me this morning? She asked me, what do you serve when a hero's coming for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 30.
dialogues.text: Jack's humble, embarrassed, doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a ballplayer, Mr. Brock.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: Tell that to all the little colored boys playing baseball in Florida today. You're a hero to them. The look on Jack's face says that's a heavy burden.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit down, have something to drink. My special rum and coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, sir, I don't drink.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: A ballplayer who doesn't drink? That's a new one on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have one. I'm a stereotypical reporter through and through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Brock, do you have a desk? I'd like to get a letter to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: Of course, this way. As Mr. Brock leads Jack ahead, Smith sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey and Montreal manager Hopper stand by the dugout watching a spring game versus St Paul. Jack's playing second. They watch him closely as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting by on a quick release, but his arm's too weak for short. Second base is his spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree. And I'll state another obvious, Clay, I need the players to act like gentlemen around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 31.
dialogues.text: The MAN on first takes a lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To treat him as they would any other teammate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be natural, to impose no restrictions on themselves. To all work together in harmony. WHACK! The hit & run is on. The man on first runs on pitch as a LOW LINE DRIVE shoots for the gap between 1st 2nd. Robinson turns himself inside out to dive on his bel and catch it before it hits the ground. He spins himself around, pivots on a knee to throw the ru out before he can get back to first. Â  Rickey is astound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was superhuman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superhuman? Don't get carried away, Mr. Rickey, that's still a Nigger out there. Rickey takes a moment to process. It's Hopper's light admonishing tone that really halts him. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, I realize that attitude is part of your heritage; that you practically nursed race prejudice at your mother's breast, so I will let it pass. But I will add this: you can manage Robinson fairly and correctly or you can be unemployed. They both look over as Jack comes off the field toward th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attaboy, Jackie! Way to turn two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith and Mr. Brock are sitting on the porch sipping rum cokes. A quiet evening.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK
dialogues.text: I hope Jackie sleeps alright. Chasing baseballs in the sun all day, I'd be in my grave. How are they treating him out there? They watch as a CAR slows, parks across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay as far as I can see. A MIDDLE-AGED WHITE MAN, LUTHER exits the car and starts  toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find good people every place you go. Even here in Florida...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it you're looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigra ball player. The air suddenly alive with danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep. Maybe you better come back in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't comin' back. Other fellas is comin'. They ain't too happy about him stayin' here in Sanford. Playin' ball with white boys. (a long beat) Skedaddle, that's what I'd do. If'n they get here, and he's still here, there's gonna be trouble. He turns and walks away. As they watch, a phone rings...

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, Wendell, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey in his pajamas in his hotel room. On the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see... Yes, I understand. Wake him up and get him out of there. Put him in the car and start driving for Daytona Beach. Now. And, Wendell, under no circumstance tell him what this is about. I do not want him to get it in his head to stay there and fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half dressed, Jack sits on the edge of his bed, feeling b Through his open door, across a hall, we can see Smith in room. Passing in and out of view packing his own things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just getting loose. Smith sticks his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't just sit there. Pack your duds. We're blowin'. A phone RINGS somewhere. They hear Brock answer, then:

dialogues.speaker: MR. BROCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Wendell?! Smith leaves the room. Hold on Jack, despair as he listen

dialogues.speaker: SMITH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Rickey, I'm with him now... We're pulling out for Daytona in five minutes, soon as he gets his bag packed... Yes, yes, it's just one of those things. âOne of those things.' As Jack's head hangs a little lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street deserted, sidewalks rolled up. Jack angry and silent in the passenger seat. Smith jumpy behind the whee They stop as a PICK-UP stops ahead outside a BAR where: A DOZEN WHITE MEN in shirtsleeves exchange words with the boys in the truck. To Jack it looks like a typical small town bull session. To Smith it looks like something else.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 34.
dialogues.text: The white men look over at the two black men. One steps over, motions: roll down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what he wants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To run us out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  The man close now. As Jack cranks down the window, Smith  floors it. The Buick SCREECHES away, SWERVING around a CA coming the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell, Wendell?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man came by while you were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told us more men were coming. Maybe  those boys. Mr. Rickey said to get  you to Daytona Beach a-s-a-p.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey was afraid you wouldn't leave, that you would fight. As it becomes clear, Jack starts to LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you woke me because I was cut from the team. Jack LAUGHS harder. Wendell LAUGHS as well. As it fades, Jack looks back over his shoulder. Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stadium SIGN boasts Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Montreal Royal

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 35.
dialogues.text: Daytona Beach's black community is turning out to see Jac Robinson. Hundreds of people line up, mass at the: Colore Entrance. In their Sunday best. Families. Couples. The old. The frail. Young boys chase after each other. One MOTHER stands on her toes to spot her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed! You stay where I can see you! 13-year old ED CHARLES turns, waves his baseball glove ov his head so she can see him. Then to no one in particular

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thirteen years old. WHITE PEOPLE enter at several gates around them.

dialogues.speaker: BRANCH RICKEY
dialogues.text: He sits watching as the segregated bleachers in right fil with BLACK FANS. All else is white. Rickey pops a PEANUT his mouth, confides to someone alongside him we don't see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spoken to the mayor. I've explained how much money we'll spend in Daytona. But still, when this fine young Negro man steps on that field today, he and the Dodgers will technically be breaking the law. A law which says white and black players cannot enjoy the same field at the same time. Does that make sense to you? Does Jim Crow make any sense when placed against the words of the United States Constitution? When placed against the word of God? POP OUT to reveal he sits beside the DODGER BATBOY, so sh his feet don't touch the ground. Rickey offers his peanut bag. As the batboy takes one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, it does not make sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack swinging two bats to get loose. Watches as the Montr BATTER hits a LINE DRIVE which -- Pee Wee Reese nearly le out of his socks to bring down. Wow... As the CROWD claps in appreciation, Jack takes a deep bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now batting the second baseman -- Jackie Robinson! Jack wincing as he steps forward to both cheers and boos the white sections. As a âgo home, coon' drifts over -- BIG OVATION from the black section in right drowns it out

dialogues.speaker: COLORED SECTION
dialogues.text: Rachel sits with Smith. They react to some of the INVECTI coming from the white section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's got a thick skin. He'll be  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get one in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higbe watching from the mound as Jack steps into the batt box. Two well wishing voices from the infield stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, black boy, you can make the grade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're giving you a chance! Do something about it! Jack heartened at the words. Concentrates as Higbe's firs pitch is fired. High and tight, Jack jerks out of the way

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 37.
dialogues.text: Bragan, behind the plate, chucks the ball back, grins up Jack who does not look down at him as he settles back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 13-year-old holding his hands together in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, God, let Jackie show them what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the next pitch. Even tighter. Jack nearly hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball two! Jack glaring, crowds the plate more. Bragan shows 1, taps his right thigh signalling outside. Jack watches it sail, doesn't bite. The umpire: âBall Three!â Higbe's fun slipping away as he can't find the strike zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rook! Ain't you gonna swing at something?! Jack takes a practice swing, waits as Bragan sets up righ over the plate. Here comes the pitch. Low. âBall four!â RACHEL & SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, over-reacting CHEER from the Colored section. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a walk. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can blame them? HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks ill-tempered over to first where Jack gives the sam look back as he sidesteps an enormous, defiant lead off t bag. Higbe incredulous. Did he just do that? DUROCHER (FROM DUGOUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well throw over there for crying out loud! Higbe fires to LAVAGETTO at first. Jack dives back in tim

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 38.
dialogues.text: Higbe gets the ball back, settles. Jack takes a lead, but modest one this time. Here come the pitch -- And Jack goe You knew he was fast; but not this fast. Bragan's throw t Pee Wee is late and high. Pee Wee throws back to Higbe.  Higbe sets. Bragan gives him a sign. Jack takes a lead. O the wind-up, Jack goes. Bragan stands -- it's a PITCH OUT Bragan fires to third and Jack is caught in a RUN DOWN. I seems like half the team gets involved with Higbe finally getting the ball by third and Jack ducking under the tag. Safe! A BUZZ goes through the stadium now as people start realize they are not watching something or someone ordina RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from a seat behind third. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thataway, Jackie! Thataway! HIGBE & JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higbe looks home for the sign, Jack dancing off third,  pounding his right foot toward home. He feints hard home. Higbe steps off the rubber. Jack stays where he is.  HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell! You're supposed to go back to third when I step off! Don't you know nothing?! He throws over. Jack back to the bag. Higbe gets the ball back, looks in. Jack bouncing, pounding off third. His  movements carry violence within them. Like a piston  exploding in an engine.  Higbe into his motion, stops his delivery, accidentally d the ball to the ground. The umpire signals BALK, points J home. Higbe is furious.

dialogues.speaker: ED CHARLES
dialogues.text: CHEERING, joyous. His mother joins in, happy despite... MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What happened? ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a balk, Mama. The pitcher can't start toward home and then stop. Jackie scores.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN REV 4-27-12 39.
dialogues.text: MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he didn't do anything. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mama, yes he did, he discombobulated the man. DUGOUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durocher looks to Branca, impressed. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't come to play; he came to kill. Durocher starts out to the mound to talk to Higbe. DIXIE WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from right field, the black crowd still cheering He walks over toward the open bullpen where Casey stands. WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This really how it's gonna be some day? Baseball? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montreal vs. Indianapolis. THE STANDS are half filled. Th COLORED SECTION is packed solid, accentuated by the many empty seats in the sections on either side of it. INSERT: De Land, Florida. No score, top of the first as -- Jack drops a BUNT down t line. The FIRST BASEMAN fields, throw to the SECOND BASEM covering. Too late. Only Jack doesn't stop. Realizing the SHORTSTOP isn't covering the bag, Jack bolt for second. The second baseman has to wait on the throw a when he makes it -- The UMPIRE signals safe. A bunt doubl Spider Jorgensen settles in the batter's box. The pitch. Crack, Jorgensen laces a single to left. Jack motors to third where Sukeforth is WAVING him home. We're with him at hip level as he tears down the basepath The CATCHER bracing for the throw - they COLLIDE - he's S As Jack gets to his feet, however, a Jim Crow POLICEMAN s up to meet him, grabs him by the shoulder. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git offa this field now!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 40.
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!? Why? POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the law is why. No niggers don't play with no white boys. Git off or go to jail. Jack shrugs the policeman's hand off his shoulder. That sends him reaching for his nightstick and -- Sukeforth is there to get between them. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You swing that thing you better hit me between the eyes with it. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? The CROWD BOOING. The black section especially. HOPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arrives from dugout) Hey, hold on, what'd he do wrong? POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't havin' Nigras mix with white boys in this town. Ya'll ain't up-states now; they gotta stay separate. Brooklyn Dodgers ain't changing our way of living. Where are you all from anyhow? HOPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenwood, Mississippi. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, man, you oughta know better. (a dangerous beat) Now tell your Nigra I said to git. You think I'm foolin'? Hopper looks desperately to Jack who just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What did you do? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Rachel out walking. He's been telling the story.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 41.
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said okay, Skipper, tell him... Ah'm a-gittin'. Sho'nuff, ah is. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. Then I took a long shower. We lost 2 to 1. She takes a few exaggerated steps to amuse him. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah'm a-gittin', ah'm a gittin'. He laughs, takes her hand. He's going to kiss her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not getting away from me. RACHEL (LOOKING PAST)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack... A white man bee-lines them from across the street, looks a real CRACKER. Jack on guard, gets in front of Rachel. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back, Rae. Go back. Cracker stops square across from him. Jack's fists balled CRACKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know something. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what's that? CRACKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know I'm pulling for you to make good. And a lot of folks here feel the same way. If a man's got the goods, he deserves a fair chance. That's all. (tips his hat) Ma'am. As Cracker walks away... Rachel takes Jack's hand. CUT TO: 52 OMITTED 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey leans against his car watching a GROUNDSKEEPER pus mow the infield grass. Jack, in street clothes, joins him JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, Mr. Rickey? Rickey nods, consider the field a moment. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the way it smells when they mow it.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 42.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.  Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let you down. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind, I've got to go tell my wife. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back.. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you believe that? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think what I believe is important. Only what I do. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed. Therefore, run the bases  like the Devil himself. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GREEN REV 4-27-12 43.
dialogues.text: RICKEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worry those pitchers so they come apart. Sometimes they'll catch you, but don't worry about that. Ty Cobb got caught plenty. Just run as you see fit. Put the natural fear of God into them. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Charles and his TWO FRIENDS follow Jack and the Montre PLAYERS as they walk toward the TRAIN waiting on the trac Jack is one of the last to board. He's almost through the door when something stops him. He looks back at Ed. A beat. Ed slowly raises his hand and waves. Jack smiles, does the same, then disappears inside. The WHISTLE blows the train starts out of the station. On impulse Ed starts trot out after it. Staying close. His friends follow. TRAIN TRACKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train picks up speed. The boys start to run. Arms pumping, feet flying. One boy drops off. Then the other. But Ed still runs. Chasing after that train carrying Jack Robinson. Finally, he stops, heaving for breath, watching the train disappear around the bend. A lonely beat. Then Ed gets down on his hands and knees. He sets his ear on t rail, closes his eyes. A thrum comes off the rail. A huge smile spreads. He straightens, shouts back to his friends ED

dialogues.speaker: I CAN STILL HEAR HIM
dialogues.text: From somewhere, as the National Anthem ends... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: April 18, 1946 - Roosevelt Stadium, Jersey City. Opening day of the International League Season. A COLOR GUARD march away to REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: PLAY BALL
dialogues.text: 30,000 FANS pack a stadium built for 24,500. Bunting and flags everywhere. 1000s of black fans are here (segregate only financially in New Jersey). CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps up to some BOOING, but much more APPLAUSE. He looks ready to beat the world. INSERT: First inning. CROWD VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jackie, this fella can't pitch! Speaking of the pitch, here it comes. Jack tops a WEAK GROUNDER to short. As he's thrown out by a mile... 56 WENDELL SMITH & RACHEL 56 Sitting up off third. His knees knocked together to hold TYPEWRITER on his lap. Nothing to write about there. He looks over at Rachel who puts her hand over her mouth. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I might be sick. (STANDING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Wendell. He watches as she starts out, looks to the field. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be sick at a swing like that, too. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel exits looking stricken. She steps over, splashes a little water from the sink up into her face. An OLDER BLA WOMAN watches sympathetically. OLDER WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, honey? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick. I don't know why. The older woman rolls off a piece of paper towel for her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. OLDER WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you have your monthly last?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 45.
dialogues.text: Rachel looks over, taken aback. But then... RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late. OLDER WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be that you're pregnant. The older woman offers a little smile, leaves her there. INSERT: Third Inning.

dialogues.speaker: P.A. ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: (ECHOING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now batting. Jackie Robinson. CUT TO: 58 HOME PLATE 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps up to bat. The JERSEY CITY GIANT PITCHER looks the Montreal RUNNER at first, glances over his shoulder a the Montreal RUNNER at second, then focuses on home. 59 SMITH 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hands resting on the top of his typewriter. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jackie. Come on, batter. 60 RACHEL 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerging up the runway. The field opening up before her. There's Jack standing down there. The sight of him settle her. As she puts a hand gently over her belly... 61 THE PITCHER 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimaces for something extra as he fires a high fastball Jack UNLOADS. All heads turn to watch it sail -- high int the left field bleachers, banging hard off the scoreboard 62 SMITH 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly drops his typewriter, pushes his hat back as he watches Jack start his home run trot. Smith laughs. Joy. 63 DUGOUT 63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopper can't believe his eyes. Softly to himself: HOPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be damned...

dialogues.speaker: WE'RE WITH JACK 64
dialogues.text: As he runs the base paths. Over it, a TYPEWRITER CLATTERS

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Robinson jogged around the bases, his heart singing... The crowd loves it as he continues toward third where Sukeforth is clapping for all he's worth.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: And our own hearts beat just a bit faster, and the thrill ran through us like champagne bubbles...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL 65
dialogues.text: Watching him head for home, shaking hands with the two me batted in. Pride & joy in her eyes. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jack... Oh Jack... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL 66
dialogues.text: Suddenly in pain, face beaded in sweat. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack! Jack! INSERT: November 18, 1946. Pasadena, California. She is in labor and we are in Huntington Memorial Hospita A CRY. The DOCTOR holds up a slick, wailing NEWBORN. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a boy. As Rachel holds out her arms for him... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack at the glass looking at JACKIE JR. Jack's eyes shine he regards his infant son. It's quiet. Jack's voice soft. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy left. He left us flat in Cairo, Georgia. I was only six months older than you are now. I don't remember him. Nothing good, nothing bad. Nothing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 47.
dialogues.text: JACK (CONT'D) (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're going to remember me. And I am going to be with you until the day I die. The stakes just got raised... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIRTY prominent BROOKLYN NEGRO leaders, representing a c section of civic responsibility, sit on folding chairs be a dais where HERBERT MILLER making an introduction. MILLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all of us know a young Negro second baseman played north of the border last season... INSERT: Brooklyn YMCA. February 5, 1947. In back: TWO DEACONS in the back whisper over a SPORTS PA DEACON ONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here what he did. (READS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Led the International League in batting: .349, in stolen bases: 40, runs scored: 113. Plus batted .400 in the Minor League World Series. DEACON TWO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last season doesn't matter. The International League, it doesn't matter. What matters is this year. What matters is Brooklyn. DEACON ONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh... Here he comes. As Herbert Miller introduces... MILLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I present the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodger baseball club, Mr. Branch Rickey! Warm APPLAUSE as Rickey steps up. As it settles... RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us. (A BEAT) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 47A.
dialogues.text: RICKEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a ballplayer on my Montreal team named Jackie Robinson. The start of applause. Rickey motions for it to stop.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 48.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a gr of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this! (pounds his fist) If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey stands waiting; giving that speech has worn him ou The door opens and Miller looks in on him.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 49.
dialogues.text: MILLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I question your bedside manner, Mr. Rickey, but they've agreed to set up a committee of self-policing. We'll call it the 'Don't Spoil Jackie's Chances' campaign. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouette of stately palms through the window. A PHO RINGS. A figure fumbles through silk sheets for the receiver. It's LEO DUROCHER, a WOMEN in bed alongside him INSERT: Beverly Hills. February 16, 1947. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, Leo, what are you doing? DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bowling. Wait, I'm snowshoeing in the Alps. I'm trying to sleep, Mr. Rickey. It's still dark out. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very early in New York. Rickey on the phone. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOLLOWING
dialogues.text: DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't got an attitude toward him. The girl rolls over to look at him. She is the actress LORRAINE DAY and she is stunning. As Durocher regards her RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 50.
dialogues.text: She puts her hands on him. (Durocher addressing Rickey.)  LORRAINE  (SOFTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...  DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know much about the Bible.  LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither...  DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't go to school just to  eat my lunch either. I'll play an elephant if he can help us win. To  make room for him, I'll send my own brother home if he's not as good. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his ear)  What are you going to do with me?  DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're playing for money, Mr. Rickey. Winning's the only thing that matters. Is he a nice guy? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. He can't afford to be. Nice guys finish last. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about nice girls?  She starts to kiss him. It's hard to concentrate. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you have no objections to him? DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None whatsoever. Can I go back to sleep now? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Oh -- and Leo? DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 50A.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's got a lot to say about a lot. Good night. Durocher hangs up the phone, looks to her.  DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do with you?  LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I thought you knew...  As she kisses him...  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands out front kissing Jackie Jr. good-bye as a CA muscles his LUGGAGE down the walkway to a waiting TAXI. J kisses Mallie and hands off the baby. Mallie carries the inside leaving Jack and Rachel alone to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 51.
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you'll write. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I ever not write? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know I'm there for you. Even if it's words on paper. He's sees she's raw, takes her in his arms with the baby. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae, you're in my heart. She sighs, rests her head on his shoulder. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting close now. The closer you get, the worse they'll be. Don't let them get to you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not. God built me to last. He kisses her. She kisses him back. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in Brooklyn in eight weeks. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be Montreal. A certainty grips her. She passes it on to him.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be Brooklyn. I know it is. Power in her words. He nods, looks off toward the taxi. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go, Rae.  She nods. They kiss, embrace a last time. He starts away  down the walk. She watches. Something not quite right.  A tug as Jack stops, looks back at her. Fighting back her emotion and then impelled forward, she runs to him. They  come together. She practically disappears in his arms. Th do not want to be apart.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durocher eats heartily. Rickey's food is untouched. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pipe dream, Mr. Rickey. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream? INSERT: Panama City, Panama. March 18, 1947. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it ain't gonna happen. The Dodgers are never gonna demand Robinson be brought up from Montreal. Ball players are conservative. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country? DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It - ain't - gonna - happen. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
