dialogues.text: I'm not saying they won't accept him: I'm saying they won't ask for him. I'm saying Robinson's good medicine, but they're not gonna like the taste. I'm saying bend over, boys, and get ready, this one might hurt a little. (ANOTHER FORKFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, this is good fish. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: KIRBY HIGBE
dialogues.text: As Higbe (South Carolina) finishes WRITING something on a piece of hotel STATIONARY, Bragan (Alabama) looks to Dixi Walker (Alabama) and Dodger pitcher HUGH CASEY (Georgia). BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think Rickey's got us playing spring games in Panama? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 53.
dialogues.text: BRAGAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to get us used to Negro crowds. He wants more of them than us. He's hoping it'll get us more comfortable being around Robinson. Higbe clears his throat, reads what he's written: HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, the undersigned Brooklyn Dodgers will not play ball on the same field as Jackie Robinson. Higbe signs it. He hands the pen to Bragan who adds his o name. Casey signs with a flourish. Casey holds out the pe to Walker who doesn't take it right away. An odd beat. CASEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wanna make your mark, Dixie, we can witness it. Everyone laughs; it loosens Walker up enough to sign. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL ROOM DOOR 76
dialogues.text: Higbe KNOCKS as Casey, Bragan and Walker crowd behind him

dialogues.speaker: STANKY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: C'mon in!

dialogues.speaker: STANKY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The boys enter. Eddie Stanky sits in a chair stripped to waist, soaking his right elbow in a BUCKET OF ICE. STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on? HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a petition goin' on, Stank. BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To keep Robinson up in Montreal where he belongs. STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Did Pee Wee sign it? HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't asked him yet. What difference does it make? STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None, just wonderin'.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 54.
dialogues.text: Stanky looks to Walker who looks away.

dialogues.speaker: STANKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: his right arm) Can't sign now. I'm indisposed. Could I catch up with you later? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: PEE WEE REESE 77
dialogues.text: Standing in the door to his room. Looking out at the glum faces of Higbe, Bragan, Casey and Walker. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's like this. I got a wife, a baby, and I got no money. I don't want to step in anything. (TO WALKER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip me, Dix, I'm not interested. WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they put him at shortstop? REESE (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's man enough to take my job, I suppose he deserves it. HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs out loud) The hell he does! WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not have the ice water in his veins for big league baseball. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let him show what he's got. Robinson can play or he can't. It'll all take care of itself. CUT TO: 78 CARL FURILLO 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very son of immigrants Rickey was talking about. From Pennsylvania no less. FURILLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the pen. Higbe grins, hands it over. As Furillo signs... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durocher lays staring up at the palm shadows on the ceili Finally, the phone rings. He answers. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Have our friends in the press gone to sleep yet? DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are the only people awake on  this entire isthmus, Mr. Rickey.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: A deliberate violation of the law, needs a little show of force. I leave it to you. Good night, Leo.  DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Rickey.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Durocher stands in a hotel bathrobe, arms cross as his PLAYERS and COACHES file in. Bleary-eyed, half- dressed, they're all here, all wondering what this is abo Suddenly, Durocher grabs the handle of an industrial-size SOUP POT and heaves it across the room. BRWANG-RANG-RANG! DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, ladies! Wake the Hell up! (a stunned beat) It's come to my attention that some of you fellas don't want to play with Robinson. That you even got a petition drawn up that you're all gonna sign. Well boys, you know what you can do with your petition?

dialogues.speaker: YOU CAN WIPE YOUR ASSES WITH IT
dialogues.text: WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Leo... DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on what?!

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 55A.
dialogues.text: WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball players gotta live together, shower together, it's not right to force him on us. Besides, I own a hardware store back home and I --

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 56.
dialogues.text: DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw your hardware store, Dix! And if you don't like it, screw you! Mr. Rickey'll be happy to make other arrangements for you. Durocher suddenly marches to Higbe, looks like he's going belt him. As Higbe gulps, Durocher turns to the team. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if he's yellow or black or has stripes like a zebra, if Robinson can help us win, and everything I've seen says he can, then he's gonna play on this ball club. Like it, lump it, make your mind up to it because he's coming! And think about this when your heads hit the pillow, he's only the first, boys, only the first. More are coming right behind him. They have talent and they wanna play! He lets that sink a moment. DUROCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, they're gonna come diving and scratching. So I'd forget your petition and worry about the field. Because unless you fellas pay a little more attention to your work, they are going to run you right out of the ball park! A petition? (looks them over) Are you ballplayers or lawyers? As he marches past them and through the doors... CUT TO: 81 OMITTED 81  82 OMITTED 82

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 57.
dialogues.text: 83 OMITTED 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack in his Montreal uniform headed off the field for the dugout. Sukeforth headed over wearing Dodger blue.  SUKEFORTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robinson!  As Jack turns, Sukeforth tosses him a FIRST BASEMAN'S GLO JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do with this? SUKEFORTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play first base. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never played first base in my  life, Coach.  SUKEFORTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's like this. Brooklyn's  got a solid second baseman. And  they got Pee Wee Reese at short.  But first base is up for grabs. Are you catching my drift? JACK  (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don't need a glove to do  that.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 58.
dialogues.text: 85 OMITTED 85

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Coach Sukeforth, getting balls from a bucket, hitting grounders down to Jack at first. The short hops are wicke Jack rolls his catches over to a little PANAMANIAN KID wh chucks them down to his brother who tosses them back to  Sukeforth. As Jack struggles...  PANAMANIAN KID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El es muy malo.  SUKEFORTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey said he wants you playing conspicuous baseball! (WHACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be so good the Dodgers'll demand you on the team! (WHACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I thought about it awhile and then I looked up conspicuous in the dictionary. (WHACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means to attract notice or attention. Jack dives, spears a liner. Sukeforth tilts back his cap. SUKEFORTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conspicuous. CUT TO: 87 OMITTED 87

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 59.
dialogues.text: 88 OMITTED 88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Bragan sits across from Rickey looking defiant. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson? BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. My friends back in Birmingham would never forgive me. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your friends here in Brooklyn? (Bragan just shrugs) Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad. BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I would quit on anyone?! I don't quit. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: 89A SECOND BASE
dialogues.text: Time slowed way down as Jack takes a throw at second from Montreal shortstop. He pivots to turn the double-play eve as Dixie Walker barrels in low.  All Jackie's focus on the task at hand as he throws while Walker submarines him. He lands in a heap tangled up  together. They both look back to see the result of the pl As Robinson smiles and Walker scowls, we know...

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Send Dixie in.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 60.
dialogues.text: 90 DIXIE WALKER 90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting down across from Rickey. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received your letter, Dixie. (READS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recently, the thought has occurred to me that a change of ball clubs would benefit both the Brooklyn Baseball Club and myself. (TO WALKER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about Robinson? WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm keeping my reasons private. Hope you can respect that, sir. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something. WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I have, Mr. Rickey, is a hardware store back home. It's called Dixie Walker's. Folks don't come because I have the lowest prices, they come because it's called Dixie Walker's. Understand? And I make as much money owning that store as I do playing for you. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you're you afraid of? (he doesn't answer) Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you! WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got my letter; can I go? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs. WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always have. That's my job.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Manhattan. April 8, 1947. Jack exits with his luggage. Looking for a cab, he sees Smith waiting. Smith offers a salute. Jack looks grumpy a he steps over. The Buick waiting beyond. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You again. Smith leans back, blinks. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Me again. Something wrong with that, Jack? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Jack continues past. As Smith follows... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic heavy. A glum silence in the car until... SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't keep you on Montreal for long. After these exhibition games, they've got to bring you up. (NO REPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have two words to rub together, do you? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to entertain you? More silence, then... SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever wonder why I sit out in right field with my typewriter on my knees? Does that ever cross your mind? Jack stares out the passenger window, not in the mood. As looks up at some of the taller buildings they pass... SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because Negro reporters aren't allowed in the press box. Jack doesn't answer, doesn't look over. Finally Smith sta talking to himself. Pretending to be Jack.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 62.
dialogues.text: SMITH âAS JACK'  You know, Wendell, I never asked you where you were from? SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I'm from Detroit, Jack. SMITH âAS JACK' You don't say? Tell me more. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy used to work at Fair Lane. That was Mr. Ford's estate. My daddy was Mr. Henry Ford's cook. SMITH âAS JACK' I did not know that. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooked for him for years, but never once broke bread with him. I'd go to work with daddy sometimes. Play baseball out on the lawn with Mr. Ford's grandchildren. We all had a real good time. But it was understood, if they got tired of playing ball and moved inside to the bowling alley or swimming pool, I was not invited or allowed. The grass was as far as I got. So guess what? You're not the only one with something at stake here. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) If I start talking, will you stop? SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to. Smith stops at a red light.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize. You've been there for me through this more than anyone besides Rae and Mr. Rickey. But I guess that's what bothers me. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like needing someone to be there for me. I don't like needing anyone but myself. I never have.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 63.
dialogues.text: SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a hard case, Jack Robinson. Is it okay if I keep driving you or should I let you out so you can walk? Jack bursts out laughing. So does Smith.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the last time we were  at a red light? Down in Florida?  SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York City now, baby. We've  come a long way.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we got a long way to go.  The light turns green. Off they go.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey reads to Parrott from the New York Sun. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players. INSERT: Brooklyn. April 9, 1947. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal. (throws paper down) For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could have Durocher hold a press conference. Demand that he get Robinson on his team.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 63A.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durocher. Of course, he's my ace in the hole. Very good, Harold. The phone still rings. Rickey looks to his open door. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Ann! Are you out there? Grumbling, brambly eyebrows twitching, he makes the mista of answering his own phone.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey... You're speaking to him... The Commissioner of what..? Oh, yes put him on. (looks to Parrott) The commissioner of baseball. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAPPY CHANDLER gets a manicure. Always jovial, a head lik an anvil with hair parted in the middle, he picks up a ph HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE FOLLOWING
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. What can I do for you, Happy? HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch, how would you feel about losing Durocher for a year? Rickey switches the phone from one ear to the other. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Happy, I thought you said lose Durocher for a year. HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He was seen in Havana with known gamblers. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who sets foot in Havana is seen with known gamblers. HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just one thing, it's an accumulation. I received notice today from the Catholic Youth Organization. Vowing a ban on baseball unless Durocher is punished for his moral looseness. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're joking. HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's this business with the actress in California. She's recently divorced and Durocher is the cause. They may even be illegally married.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 65.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm sure you're joking. Happy checks his nails, returns his hand to the MANICURIS HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I were. The CYO buy a lot of tickets, Branch. They draw a lot of water and I can't afford to ruffle their feathers. Am I mixing metaphors there? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know very well my organization is about to enter a tempest. I need Durocher at the rudder. He's the only man who can handle this much trouble, who loves it in fact. You're chopping off my right hand! HAPPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no choice. I'm going to have to sit your manager, Branch. Leo Durocher is suspended from baseball for a year. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that! Happy, you son of a bitch! DIAL TONE. Rickey steadies himself, looks to Parrott. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble ahead, Harold. Trouble. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durocher, in a suit, cleans out his locker. Carefully set each item in a cardboard box. Finished, he closes the loc door. CLICK. And then -- WHAM! -- Drives his fist in, tak it off its hinges. He picks up his box, quietly walks out CUT TO:  96 OMITTED 96

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 66.
dialogues.text: 97 OMITTED 97  98 OMITTED 98  99 OMITTED 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RING... Jack asleep in bed, fumbles for the receiver.  INSERT: April 10, 1947.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JANE ANN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Robinson, this is Jane Ann in  Mr. Rickey's office. He needs to  see you right away. He has a  contract for you to sign.  That wakes him up.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits at the desk. Alone. He looks back over his  shoulder at the GOLDFISH. As one of them stares back, Ric enters with the CONTRACT in question. He sets it down bef Jack, hands him a pen.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry about the rush.  Events are unfolding too fast to  keep up with. The burden has  finally fallen to me and so be it.  JACK  (POINTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign here?  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.  As Jack poises the pen -- Rickey suddenly aghast.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!  The pen a millimeter over the page.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History. And I'm blabbing,  blabbing through history... Rushing  it along. What am I thinking?

dialogues.speaker: 99C RICKEY'S OUTER OFFICE 99C
dialogues.text: Rickey sticks his head out the door. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Ann, come in here. (hollering down hall) Harold! Parrott sticks his head out from an office down the hall. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some employees up here!  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: 99D RICKEY'S DESK 99D
dialogues.text: Where Jack Robinson signs his contract. As he sets the pe down -- Rickey starts APPLAUDING. He's joined by Parrott, JANE ANN and a JANITOR. Rickey claps Jack on the shoulder RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, telegram the press. Say this: âThe Brooklyn Dodgers today purchased the contract of Jackie Robinson from the Montreal Royals. He will report immediately.â As Jack takes it in, he's the only one not smiling. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Rachel answers in her nightgown. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Rae, I'm in Brooklyn. Brooklyn... Rachel lets out a triumphant WHOOP! RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few lights twinkle, but this city does occasionally sle

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 67.
dialogues.text: 101 JACK 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man does not. He stands bare chested in his boxers staring out the window of a MCALPIN HOTEL ROOM. Consideri the world before him. Wondering where his place is in it. INSERT: April 15, 1947. 3 AM. It's a lonely moment. Until Rachel appears behind him in nightgown. She wraps her arms around him, looks over his shoulder at the world out there. Finally, softly... RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you... As he closes his eyes, absorbs it... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack cruises down, stops in front of the PEPTO BISMOL. INSERT: April 15, 1947. 11 AM. As he grabs a bottle -- a man on the other side pulls one as well. Jack finds himself looking at Pee Wee Reese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Reese exit together, each with a bottle of Pepto Bismol in hand. Reese hefts his bottle.  REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening day nerves. Doing my stomach something awful. Jack nods in commiseration. It's awkward between them. A RUMBLE as a GARBAGE TRUCK goes by. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes another one. (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I see a garbage truck go by I still can't figure why the guy driving isn't me. JACK (SMILES BACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd both better get on base. Reese nods. They start walking toward the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 68.
dialogues.text: REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know when I first heard of you? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a troop transport, coming back from Guam. A sailor heard it on the radio, told me the Dodgers had signed a Negro player. I said that was fine by me. Then he said the guy was a shortstop. Least you were then. That got me thinking. Thinking gets me scared. Jack smiles, hefts his bottle of Pepto. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black, white, we're both pink today, huh? (REESE NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still scared, Pee Wee? REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks down street) Of garbage trucks? Terrified. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taj Mahal of baseball. Opening day.  INSERT: Ebbets Field. Brooklyn.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guys quiet, some guys joking around. Everyone in som version of getting out of their street clothes or into th uniforms. The entire operation comes to a halt as -- Jack enters. As he walks past -- some players nod hello. Others look like Sphinxes. Walker turns and faces his locker. Gene Hermanski and Branca step over to SHAKE HAND HERMANSKI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Hermanski. Welcome to Brooklyn. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man. Ralph Branca. Last, but not least, Spider Jorgensen, his Montreal teamm

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 68A.
dialogues.text: JORGENSEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it, Jack, huh? Good luck. That's it. Everyone else is too busy to come over. As Jac scans for a locker with his name on it, BABE HAMBURGER, t clubhouse manager, steps over.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 69.
dialogues.text: BABE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking for your locker, huh, kid? Follow me. They walk over to a hook on the wall. A uniform hangs fro it. A FOLDING CHAIR below.

dialogues.speaker: BABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just got the word. Best I could do. I'll get you straightened out tomorrow though, huh? Jack nods, unbuttoning his shirt... Stanky is suddenly th All pugnacity as he gives up 4 inches and 40 pounds to Ja STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're putting on that uniform, it means you're on my team. But before I play with you I want you to know how I feel about it. I want you to know I don't like it. I want you to know I don't like you. Jack regards him. Stanky doesn't flinch. Maybe he should. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. That's how I prefer it. Right out in the open. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HOT DOG VENDER
dialogues.text: Standing before his steaming HOT DOG STAND. VENDOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Brooklyn! Get your Harry M. Stevens special here! As he hands one over, gets his .20 cents in return. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Lady! Rachel looks over, baby Jackie in her arms. The vendor ta a baby bottle out of the hot water in his STEAMER.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it's ready. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: JACK ROOSEVELT ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Looking at himself in a MIRROR. Standing in his uniform, clean white wool, the flowing script: Dodgers. It fits.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 70.
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW HIM past Stanky as he goes. Follow the BLUE 42 his back as he steps through the clubhouse.

dialogues.speaker: MAKES HIS WAY UP THE TUNNEL. 107
dialogues.text: Always on that magic number as he comes up through the Do DUGOUT and steps onto... 108 EBBETS FIELD 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHOTOGRAPHERS snap photos, the crowd spot him and CHEER. 109 RACHEL 109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watches from the stands. Pleased at the cheering. She hol the baby up to see, whispers to him... RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, that's good. As Jackie's eyes find hers... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE PLAYERS LINED UP FOR THE NATIONAL ANTHEM 110
dialogues.text: The Dodgers down one baseline, the BOSTON BRAVES down the other. Forty-nine white players and one black. Jack at th end alongside Ralph Branca. Jack trying not to choke up. EVERETT MCCOOEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'er the land of the free! And the home of the brave! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players not starting return to the dugout. Bragan catches up with Branca. BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy standing that close to him. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? BRAGAN (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if the sharpshooter misses and hits you instead? BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a serious problem, Bragan, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 71.
dialogues.text: BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I don't see it. CUT TO: 112 BRANCH RICKEY 112

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surveying the scene. Parrott alongside. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening day, Harold. The world is all future and no past. PARROT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blank page, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED BARBER looks down onto the field. BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One out in the bottom of the first. Headed toward the plate for his first big league at bat is Dodger rookie Jackie Robinson. Jackie is very definitely brunette. 114 JACK 114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walks toward the plate. More cheers. Mostly. FAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with you, Jackie! FAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boy, how about a shine?! Jack struggles not to look back at the source of the jeer He settles in at the plate. JOHNNY SAIN on the mound wait for the sign. The crowd BUZZING.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sain looking in. When he's got that fastball working, he can toss a lamb chop past a hungry wolf. The BRAVES CATCHER signals â1'. Here come the pitch. CR It's down the third base line. The THIRD BASEMAN is going to need every ounce of his arm he fields it at the line, throw across his body to -- FIRST. Where Jack's foot hits the bag an instant before t ball smacks into the first baseman's mitt.

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 72.
dialogues.text: UMPIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out! Jack can't believe it. As he trots toward the dugout he looks at the umpire who looks back: I dare you to complai STANDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Brooklyn faithful BOO the call, Rachel and Smith w Jack head decisively toward the dugout. He was safe. Rickey sits down closer to the dugout. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a game of inches, Jackie! PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some glasses, ump! CUT TO: 115 OMITTED 115  116 OMITTED 116  117 OMITTED 117  118 OMITTED 118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT SHOTTON, 62, walks down the hallway with Parrott.  INSERT: April 18, 1947.  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Florida, Burt?  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roses need pruning, but fine when I  left it last night. Branch said it  was important and I heard about  Leo. Any idea what this is about?  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better just talk to him.  A beat as they reach the door. Parrott knocks.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey smiles from his desk as they enter.

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 73.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball has returned to Brooklyn, Burt. Another season is underway. SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a shame about Leo. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inevitable I suppose. I asked him if she was worth it and he said yes. How's the retirement? SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. The roses --  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a helluva thing when a man has  good health and enough money and absolutely nothing to do. SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm perfectly happy.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I took off that Cleveland  uniform two years ago, I promised the Mrs. I'd never put on another uniform again. Roses look great  and I sleep a whole lot better.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roses and sleep are two wonderful  things, Burt. But sleep you can  get inside your casket and flowers  look good on top of it. You don't  look like a dead man to me.  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about, Branch?

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 73A.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to manage the Dodgers.  We're a ship without a captain; there's a typhoon ahead. SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry, but no.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you miss the game, Burt? Look  me in the eye and tell me you  don't.  Shotton considers Rickey a beat and then looks away.  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball's the only life for an old  pepper pot like me, but I promised  my wife, Branch. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised her you wouldn't put on another uniform. You didn't promise her you wouldn't manage.  Wear a suit and tie; Connie Mack  still does.  (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember how to get to the Polo  Grounds, Burt?  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch, I --  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember what the peanuts smell  like roasting, how the crack of the  bat sounds, the roar of the crowd?  SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...  Rickey tosses him a set of car keys.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car's parked right out front.  Harold will show you where. Now  what do you say? SHOTTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotton addresses the half-dressed Dodgers, Jack included SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men, I don't have much to say. Just, don't be afraid of old Burt Shotton as a manager. You can win the pennant in spite of me. I can not possibly hurt you. The Dodgers trade looks. Not exactly inspirational. As Shotton heads out he pauses by Jack. SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Robinson? (JACK NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. Shotton pats Jack on the shoulder, continues on his way. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge CROWD beyond. Bob Cooke of the Herald Tribune (see at the Waldorf Astoria) holds court as Jack is ANNOUNCED. COOKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark my words and circle this date. Negroes are going to run the white man straight out of baseball. I'm not prejudiced; it's physiological. They have a longer heel bone. Gives em an unfair speed advantage.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Standing dead still at the plate, bat cocked and ready.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Here's Robinson. Jackie holds that  club down by the end. Rear foot on  the back line of the box. Slight  open stance, bent at the knees...  Giants pitcher DAVE KOSLO goes into his wind-up and throw Jack swings. CRACK. The ball screams out to left. Home run! The crowd goes crazy. This is what they came to see. 122 PRESS BOX 122

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typewriters pounding away as Jack finishes his home run t Bob Cooke watching thoughtfully as...

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 74A.
dialogues.text: ANOTHER REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that because his heels are longer, Bob?! As everyone cracks up, everyone but Bob... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Rachel out for dinner. Jack nodding as BLACK PATRONS pass by, saying encouraging things. He almost get forkful of food to his mouth before a MENU and a PEN are offered for an autograph. As he signs, a FLASH BULB goes off. In a lull, Jack cuts his steak, low to Rachel. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not complaining, I just, I don't know what they want. RACHEL (BEAMING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to see if Jackie Robinson is real. They want to see your pride, your dignity. Because then they'll see it in themselves. He's stopped short. She blinks with mock coquettish modes

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And me? I'm just young and scared and amazed at how brave you are. He grins at her, almost gets a forkful in when LAWSON BOW the Black owner, pulls up a chair, shakes Jack's hand. OWNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Lawson Bowman, Jack, the owner of this joint. How's the steak? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure yet. It looks good. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHROOM MIRROR - Steamed. A finger traces â42' in the on the glass, then wipes it clean to reveal Rachel. Hair  wrapped in a towel, she looks at herself, frowns.  INSERT: Brooklyn, April 22, 1947.  DRYING DIAPERS - Hang like pennants on a line stretched  across the BEDROOM. Rachel ducks under them to retrieve h shoes. She looks at them, frowns.  RACHEL - Brushing her teeth. Pauses to hold the toothbrus in a batting stance. Swings...  RACHEL - Strains to reach to zip her dress up. She pulls the edges of the dress, straightens herself out. She look over at Jack Jr. who watches from his crib.

dialogues.speaker: DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 75A.
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky you're a boy. DOORWAY - Dressed to go, Rachel holding the baby, looking anxiously out on the street. Suddenly, ALICE the baby-sit is there. Here she comes up the steps, opens the door. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. Class ran long. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Rachel gently hands the baby over. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so cold and raw out, I don't want him getting sick at the game. ALICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be nice and warm here. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks her watch) I'm going to be late. She kisses him goodbye, frowns as she heads outside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forboding sky above as Rachel hurries along. Pulling he jacket on as she goes. It's going to be a cold day.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The sky's are leaden. Threatening.  Eddie Stanky safe at first as  Robinson steps to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooklyn vs. Philadelphia. The bottom of the first. The crowd CHEERS. Stanky safe on first.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The sky's are leaden. Threatening. Eddie Stanky safe at first as Robinson steps to the plate. Jack walk to the plate, digs a cleat into the batter's bo

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey you black Nigger! Jack looks to the visitor's dugout where the Phillies Ala born manager BEN CHAPMAN stands at the top of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 75AA.
dialogues.text: CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go back to the cotton fields where you belong!

dialogues.speaker: GREEN REV 4-27-12 76.
dialogues.text: The bear baiting has begun. Jack is in a kind of temporar shock. That's the Phillies manager! In uniform. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or did you swing your way out of the jungle?! Bring me a banana!

dialogues.speaker: 124A RED BARBER
dialogues.text: BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapman the Phillies manager up on the top step, seems to be chirping something out to Robinson. Chapman a hothead during his playing days with the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: RICKEY
dialogues.text: Sitting next to Parrott. He leans forward, unsure. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying? 126 VISITOR DUGOUT 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapman joined by two of his PHILLIE BENCH PLAYERS.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIE ONE PHILLIE TWO
dialogues.text: Go home, Nigger! Go back to Africa! Phillie pitcher DUTCH LEONARD looks in. Jack has to try t concentrate on the pitch. Here it comes. A fastball well inside. Jack hits the deck to keep from getting beaned.  CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bojangles! You sure can dance, snowflake! STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On first, mouth hanging open. Almost forgets to take a le It's an instant Rorschach test. DODGER DUGOUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotton and the players look stricken. Even Walker doesn' quite know what to make of it. No one enjoys it, but Higb STANDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONCESSION MEN walk closer to listen. The fans range from horrified to some mildly pleased. Rachel looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 76A.
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fastball inside. He leaps back again. This one was even closer to hitting him. As Jack glares at Dutch... UMPIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball two!

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey, black boy! Hey, shoe shine!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 77.
dialogues.text: Jack doesn't want to look over, but he is compelled. The bench players flanking Chapman look furious, but Chapman doing this with a sick sort of glee. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like white girls?! Huh?! Which one of them Dodger boys' wives are you climbing on tonight?! Chapman looks toward... DODGER DUGOUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't like that one.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, I think I got it. Dixie, I believe I know! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grips the bat. Watches for the next pitch with bloody mindedness. He hacks at it, lofts a routine fly into left He's about halfway down to first when the left fielder catches it and Jack can mercifully return to the dugout. 127 RICKEY 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey watches as he disappears inside. Finally exhales. 128 BENCH 128

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits down. No one says anything to him. No one comes near him as he stares ahead, trapped in a kind of void. T closest player to him is Bobby Bragan. Bragan finally manages to glance over at him, then looks quickly away. CUT TO: 129 RACHEL 129

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Dodgers take the field, Jack heads to first. Almos wincing, wondering if it's going to start again. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Look at me, baby. Look at me. Finally, Jack glances up to her. She offers her eyes: I'm with you. He looks away. Her witnessing makes it worse. 130 BEN CHAPMAN 130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settles back in the shadows of the dugout. Finished for n CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 78.
dialogues.text: 131 DODGER SCOREBOARD 131

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No score. Bottom of the 3rd. INFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spider Jorgensen takes a lead off first. At the plate, Stanky lines a single to right. Jorgensen holds at second JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps to the batter's box, starts digging in that back fo

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR'S DUGOUT
dialogues.text: As Chapman emerges with his two bench players.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIE ONE PHILLIE TWO
dialogues.text: Hey, Nigger lips! Party's over, jungle bunny!  CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pee Wee! Dixie! What's this Nigger doing for you all to let him drink from the same water fountain as you?! I hope it's worth it! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for the pitch. Takes a mighty swing -- CRACKS a towering POP-UP between home plate and the mound. Dutch watches his catcher Seminick settle under it. Waiting. DUTCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, is that a home run!? SEMINICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! If you're playing in an elevator shaft! Jack veers off the first baseline. Heads for the dugout. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't belong! Look in a mirror! This is a white man's game. Get it through your thick monkey skull! Jack stops short looks at him. Chapman stands his ground. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stands, watches. Praying this doesn't go south. As Jack finally continues on, Rickey closes his eyes in relief. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick for her husband.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 79.
dialogues.text: THE DUGOUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stalks down past the team. No one looks at him. Brag is ashamed. Dixie tries to look disinterested. Stanky and Reese exchange a helpless glance as Jack continues into: 132 THE TUNNEL 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a bull on his way to slaughter, he revolts. WHAM-WHA He proceeds to turn his bat into SPLINTERS. Concrete chip wood flies. Jack drops the handle of the bat, pounds his fists. Heaving for breath, framed by the empty tunnel. Ra electric, ungovernable. All the anger on display, the fur FEET SCRAPE. Jack looks up to see Rickey standing there, watching, afraid to get too much closer. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with this. The next white son of a bitch who opens his mouth, I'll smash his goddamn teeth in. Rickey stands there until finally, opening his mouth... RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't, Jackie. You know it. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to let this go on? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men have to live with THEMSELVES -- JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to live with myself, too! And right now I'm living a sermon out there. I'm through with it! Jack is at the end of his rope. All Rickey has are words. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't matter right now, Jack. You're in this thing. You don't have the right to pull out from the backing of people who believe in you, respect you and who need you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you fight, they won't say Chapman forced you to; they'll just say that you're over your head. That you belong where you are. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 80.
dialogues.text: RICKEY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That every downtrodden man who wants more from life is over his head. Jack's either going to explode or break into tears. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it's like, having someone do this to you?! RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You do. You're the one living the sermon. In the wilderness. Forty days. All of it. Only you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not a damn thing I can do about it. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course there is! You can stand up and hit! You can get on base and you can score! You can win this game for us! We need you as well! Everyone needs you. (a beat; exhausted) You're medicine, Jack. Rickey reaches out, touches the wall to stay standing. Ja just breathes as familiar sounds reverb down the tunnel. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're taking the field. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's playing first? Jack considers him. Everything hangs in the balance. Then JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna need a new bat. As Jack heads back down the tunnel for the field. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight zeros hang for the Phillies. Seven for the Dodgers. No score, the bottom of the 8th coming up. 134 JACK 134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps into the batter's box. Chapman and his sidekicks st from the Stygian abyss of the visitor's dugout.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 81.
dialogues.text: CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, black Nigger! I know you can hear me! If you were a white boy, you know where you'd be right now?! On a bus headed down to Newport News cuz you can't play for shit! Here comes the pitch. Jack nonchalantly sticks his bat ou pokes a soft hit past second. A nothing hit, but he's standing on first. And he looks, well, ferocious in fact. As Pete Reiser steps up into the batter's box... Jack stares at Dutch Leonard. Assassin's eyes as he takes insolent, in-your-face lead off first. Dutch fires to first. Jack dives back safe! Back on his feet, he spits out a piece of grit he picked sliding back on his belly. Not bothering to dust himself off, he's turning into something elemental before our eye 135 RED BARBER 135

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in the booth. BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two strikes now to Reiser as Leonard looks in. Robinson with another big lead off first. He's as  restless as a cat with a hot foot.  136 RACHEL 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witnessing. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steal it, sweetheart. Take it. 137 FIELD 137

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch throws. Jack on the run as Reiser swings and misses STRIKE THREE! - and Seminick comes up throwing. Jack slides into second, the throw high, ends up in cente Half a dozen Dodgers impulsively on their feet and waving on as Jack gets to his feet and motors into THIRD. The th well late. Phillies third baseman HANDLEY throws the ball back to Dutch. Handley then looks to Jack. HANDLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I want you to know what goes on here, it don't go for me. Jack barely nods, but he heard.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hermanski steps up. PLATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch looking to third, nodding distracted at a sign, loo back to third before... Hermanski cracks a single to left As Jack crosses the plate, he stares down Chapman on his to the dugout. As Chapman turns his head, spits -- CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several REPORTERS around Chapman as well. He drinks a BEE CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fellas are making too big a deal out of this. He scored We lost. One to nothing. REPORTER THREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you were a little hard on Robinson? CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We treat him the same way we do Hank Greenburg except we call Hank a kike instead of a coon. When we play exhibitions against the Yankees, we call DiMaggio the Wop. They laugh at it. No harm, it's forgotten after the game ends. Chapman tosses away his beer can. REPORTER THREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think this was maybe one foot over the line? CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Let's get the chips off our shoulders and play ball. It's a game, right? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack alone in the shower. Water beating down. Steam risin A warrior who survived another day of battle. Maybe. They say the Lord doesn't ask us to bear any more than we're a but God is cutting it pretty damn close here. He is in pa CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey sits brooding, thinking. Parrott enters, upset. PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going in that Phillie dugout tomorrow and wring Chapman's neck! Rickey considers Parrott, starts laughing. Parrott is hur PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say something funny? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I first told you about Jackie, you were against it. Now all of a sudden you're worrying about him. How do you suppose that happened? PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, any decent minded person -- RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sympathy, Harold, is a Greek word. It means to suffer. I sympathize with you means I suffer with you. This Philadelphia manager has done me a service. PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A service?! RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there an echo in here? Yes, he's creating sympathy on Jackie's behalf. Philadelphia by the way is Greek for brotherly love. The intercom BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: JANE ANN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Bob Bragan to see you, Mr. Rickey. RICKEY (FLASHES ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in Satan's fire does he want? (PRESSES BUTTON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him in. Rickey pretends to review papers as Bragan enters, his ha literally in his hand. Rickey lets him stand there a mome RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Bragan?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 84.
dialogues.text: BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like not to be traded, sir, if it isn't too late. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Robinson? Bragan's been staring at the floor. He looks up now. The low afternoon sun hits his face. BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to be his teammate. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's changing; I guess I can live with the change. RICKEY (SARCASTIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Sox just offered Ted Williams, but I'll see what I can do. BRAGAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Rickey. Bragan leaves. Rickey looks at Parrott: âWhat do you kn CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel waiting. Jack exits, sees her, hadn't expected her JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have waited. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't made a day long enough that I wouldn't wait for you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give these boys time. It's a three game series. A beat between them, framed by the steel girders around t

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't care if they like me; I didn't come here to make friends. I don't even care if they respect me. I know who I am; I got enough respect for myself. But I do not want them to beat me.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 85.
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are never going to beat you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're taking their best shot. I don't want you coming tomorrow. I don't want you to watch that, them beating me. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever you are, I am, too. Look at me. Jack... He looks over. It's not easy for this most proud of men. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to watch. So our hearts don't break... Plus I already bought a scorecard. She holds it up. His name the only one filled in. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I put your name on it. See? Jack Robinson. He puts his hand out, takes hers. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did good the day I met you. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you hit a home run. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCOREBOARD shows 1 run scored by the Phillies in the of the first. Jack steps up to the plate. Here we go agai INSERT: April 23, 1947. The next day.  CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, porch monkey! Hey Robinson! Hey boy! You know why you're here? EDDIE STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bench. Without warning, he blasts off it. MOVE WIT him as he marches toward Chapman who doesn't see him comi CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here to draw those Nigger dollars at the gate for Rickey!

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 86.
dialogues.text: Chapman clocks the apoplectic Stanky. Spit flying as: STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. Sit down or I'll sit you down. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem, Stank? STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the problem, you goddamn disgrace! What kind of man are you?! You know he can't fight! Pick on someone who can fight!

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (OVER IT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Stanky having a chin wag with  his ex-teammate Chapman. Both men  masters of distraction. Eddie, of  course, from second. Chapman from  the dugout.  Stanky so mad he can't see straight. Chapman surrenders. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Jesus. As Chapman disappears into his dugout, Jack whacks a sing CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanky sits here stewing. His head down.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Robinson on first, Pete Reiser at  bat. Reiser belts it. A long one.  Deep into left center. Back goes  Ennis who is not tall enough. This  one's off the wall. Robinson is  going to score from first.  Over Barber: a CRACK of the bat, the ROAR of the crowd. A players around him react, Stanky finally looks up as Robi crosses the plate, heads in, sits a few feet from Stanky. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? You're on my team. What the hell am I supposed to do? (SOFTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta look in the mirror, too.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 86A.
dialogues.text: Stanky stands, walks away. Today's gonna be okay. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK PREACHER leads his congregation in prayer. PREACHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, make me an instrument of your peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love. Where there is injury, let me sow pardon. Where there is darkness, let me sow light. âAmens'. We see Rickey sits in the back row, the day he on him. A YOUNG GIRL turns, looks at him. Why's a white m here? Rickey smiles, puts a finger to his lips... Shhhh. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players put on their uniforms as Higbe, in street clothes fires the contents of his locker into a cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 87B.
dialogues.text: HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak my mind and they trade me! This ain't the America I know! He glares down to Jack's locker. Jack regards him back. It's Higbe who looks away first. He continues packing. WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they sending you, Hig? HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh! For cash and some I- talian outfielder named Gionfriddo! (CONSIDER HIS JOCKSTRAP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dixie Walker takes batting practice, drives the ball all the field. A natural. Rickey and Shotton watch from behind the backstop. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the story, Burt, of the 99 sheep? How one was missing? SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're talking about Dixie, I'd leave the word sheep out of it. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find myself at odds. I want integration and the pennant. I want to punish Dixie and at the same time I want his salvation. SHOTTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't he just be a good ballplayer? He has to be a good person, too? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be so much simpler if he wasn't batting .385.  As Walker finishes, he passes Jack whose turn it is.  WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all yours, Robinson.  As THUNDER rumbles in the distance...  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 88.
dialogues.text: 147 OMITTED 147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain beats on the windows. Rickey looks over as Parrott  rushes in; he's out of breath and dripping wet. Parrott  holds up the Herald Tribune sports section.  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news isn't good, sir.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless it must be accepted  calmly, Harold. What is it?  A headline: PLAYERS STRIKE. Parrott reads...  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A National League players' strike  instigated by some of the St. Louis Cardinals against the presence of Negro first baseman Jackie Robinson has been averted temporarily and perhaps permanently quashed. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness! What are they thinking?!  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell Smith waits under an umbrella as the CARDINALS ge off the team bus. Smith buttonholes manager EDDIE DYER. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, what's all this talk about your Cardinals refusing to play? DYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here, aren't we? We didn't come to New York to go to Macy's. Dyer continues past him. Here comes big JOE GARAGIOLA. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Garagiola -- GARAGIOLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost. Here comes STAN MUSIAL, a class act if there ever was one SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stan, what's the story?

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 88A.
dialogues.text: MUSIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is big league baseball, not  English tea. Couple a guys  might've popped off; it's hot air.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith types out his report. As rain lashes the window, th Empire State building looms a few block away.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: St. Louis didn't win the world championship last year without using their heads. They have the same heads this year and should know that they can't pick the players of another club. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits here alone, tending to a bat. Cleaning it with rubbing alcohol, handling it like the friend it is. Ricke joins him. He has a newspaper in hand. He holds it up. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: National League President Frick says this is America and baseball is America's game. He says one citizen has as much right to play as another. (LOOKS UP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball will go on as planned once  the rain stops.  Jack eyes his bat. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my job is to win. I have an obligation to Brooklyn to put the best team on the field I can. Your presence on the roster increases our chances of winning. Not buying it, Jack looks over at him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is winning, I'd hate to see us on a losing streak. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys change into their street clothes. Branca reads to Re from the New York Post. Walker listens in from his locker BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this: Right now Robinson  is the loneliest man I have ever  seen in sports.  (UPSET)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this guy to say Jackie's  lonely? He doesn't wear it on his  sleeve. Man's got one helluva game  face. Take no prisoners. How does  some reporter know how he feels.  They stop talking as Robinson walks past, the last one in the shower, a couple of towels around him.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 89A.
dialogues.text: BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonely? I say its the best game  face in the world.  WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as he showers lonely, he  can have whatever face he wants.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel sitting here. This section about two-thirds full.  INSERT: May 6, 1947. Brooklyn. Then, about five rows behind her, two RACIST FANS find th seats. They spot Jack down at first. RACIST FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look there he is! Black as the ace of spades!

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 90.
dialogues.text: RACIST FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! You believe that? A genuine nigger in a Dodger uniform. As Rachel winces at his words -- BROOKLYN FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and go back to St. Louis! RACIST FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you got a nigger on your team! BROOKLYN FAN #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?! He's better than anyone you got! RACIST FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll his cousin wants your job! Don't you know nothing? BROOKLYN FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?! RACIST FAN #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a nigger! Hey, black boy! Rachel stares ahead, tries to maintain. She shows them he back, sits up as straight as she can. Her movements heroi CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps up against the Cardinals. Garagiola, the catch shouts down to third. GARAGIOLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this guy! He can't hit! Especially the curve! He can only get on base bunting! As Jack digs into the box. GARAGIOLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time, Robinson, you're digging your own grave. Big RED MUNGER looks in for the sign. Garagiola flashes a sign: â1'. Wants it inside. Here's the pitch. Inside. Jack just scoots back.

dialogues.speaker: 152A RED BARBER
dialogues.text: BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes a fastball in on the hands. Robinson, who is pitched to a great deal that way, uses a thicker handle bat than most hitters, just because he hits a lot of balls out on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: 152B BATTER'S BOX 152B
dialogues.text: Jack edges up closer to the plate. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your average, Joe? GARAGIOLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd be a lot higher than yours, if I could run as fast as you can. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how fast you run, you'll never hit as much as you weigh. Garagiola signals for another fastball. GARAGIOLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Munger! Boy's got a hole in his bat! Munger throws inside. Jack falls back, strokes a double into the gap.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That one wasn't quite âin' enough. Robinson punishing the Redbirds with a smart piece of hitting. RETURN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brooklyn fans cheer; the Racist fan sulks. The double little comfort to Rachel who stares ahead, sitting as straight up as she can. Willing herself not to cry. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 91.
dialogues.text: 153 OMITTED 153

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Rachel ride home. Forlorn, she stares out. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jack... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Rae? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's just, sometimes when I sit up there with those bastards,  those loudmouths in the stands, I  know you can hear them.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's okay.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not okay. And I can hear  them, too.  Jack looks at her, takes her hand in his.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry for that.  Rachel squeezes his hand back.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in it together. When they  start in on you, you know what I do? I try to sit up as straight.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight as I can.  (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 92.
dialogues.text: RACHEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it in my head that I can block it from you, some of it, if I sit up straight. (a sad smile) Isn't that dumb? Closing the space between them, he takes her hand. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It worked. I didn't hear a thing. She tries to smiles. As the tears streak her cheeks, he leans in kisses her forehead. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just ignorant. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they knew you, they'd be ashamed. She puts her arm around him, draws that strength. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am holding on. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as we hold on, it'll be okay. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHACK! Rachel and Rickey watch Jack taking batting practi RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look lovely, Mrs. Robinson. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you do it. Every day, from the 1st to the 9th. Myself? I could pay $100 for a suit and in twenty minutes I'd look like I fell out of bed. Even my shoes look rumpled. They watch Jack crack one high off the Schaefer Beer sign RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to think Jack was conceited.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 93.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the very first thing I noticed about him. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you two meet? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him at a UCLA football game. Even in uniform with a helmet on, his vanity was awful. It was the  way he held his hands on his hips. I hated him! (RICKEY LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on campus he always wore crisp white shirts and I'd think his skin is so dark, why would he do that? Then I got to know him, his pride and confidence, and I realized he was showing off his color. I was wrong. He wasn't conceited; he was  proud. Always, of who and what he  is. I'd never met another man like that. What about you? How did you meet your wife? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to catch her in a race. She was the fastest girl in town. Beautiful legs. I finally caught up; we've been together ever since. They sit a moment. Below: Jack nails another one. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to apologize to you. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. I can't apologize to him. He and I both knew what we were getting into. But you. A newlywed, trying to blossom a marriage under all this pressure. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me. Or us. We know who we are. Crack. Jack hits another.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 94.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband has humbled me. When this all began I thought I was changing the world and that Jackie was my instrument. Can you imagine? I wish I could help him, but I'm just a spectator. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You help him plenty. Believe me. They watch him rip into another pitch. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he able to get things off his chest? So he doesn't burn up? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I have to let him have that silence at first, let him come to me. But he opens up eventually. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It's too much to carry inside. Does he have any friends on the team? (she gives him a look) They're spectators, too. They do admire him though. Rachel looks out to where Reese and Stanky play catch. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think so? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the worst of us recognizes courage. Moral courage especially. I have to think they see it. Jackie's a man on trial. He's responding with glory and grace. No one can take their eyes off him. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had himself on trial since the day I met him. No man is harder on himself or gets to himself worse than Jack. But I hope his team- mates know, they're on trial too. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we all are. You're an astute woman, Mrs. Robinson.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 95.
dialogues.text: RACHEL (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be, Mr. Rickey, I'm married to a man of destiny. I can't let him down. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'd met you first, I wouldn't  have looked so long for Jackie.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean?  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean if he was good enough for  you, he's certainly good enough for  the rest of us.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillie GM HERB PENNOCK at his desk, on the phone. PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch, it's Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: THE FOLLOWING
dialogues.text: PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have we known each other? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years. Maybe more. PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then trust me when I say, Brooklyn's due here tomorrow, but you can not bring that Nigger down here with the rest of your team. Rickey grits his teeth, stays civil. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why's that, Herb? His name's Jackie Robinson by the way. PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just not ready for this sort of thing in Philadelphia. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 95aA. PENNOCK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure we'll be able to take the field against your team if that boy is in uniform. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbert, what your team does is your decision. But my team is coming to Philadelphia. With Robinson. If we have to claim the game as a forfeit, we will. That's 9-0 in case you forgot.

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 95A.
dialogues.text: PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch, you've got one helluva hair  across your ass on this thing and  I, for one, would like to know what  you're trying to prove?  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think God likes baseball? I  do.  PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you're going to meet God  one day, Herb, and when he inquires  why Robinson wasn't on the field in  Philadelphia and you answer because  he was a Negro, it may not be a  sufficient reply.  As Rickey hangs up the phone...  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 96.
dialogues.text: 158 OMITTED 158

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dodger TEAM BUS pulls up. The doors whoosh open; Parr steps off looking official. As the players start to follo INSERT: May 9, 1947. Benjamin Franklin Hotel, Philadelphi PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, fellas! We have twenty  minutes to check in and then get to  Shibe! Chop chop.  No one is listening as the TEAM DRIVER opens the lower  compartment and the players (including Jack) grab their b HOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! Get that bus out of here!  The HOTEL MANAGER stalks over, flanked by HOTEL SECURITY. PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the Dodgers. We have a  reservation.  HOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your team's not welcome, not while  you have ballclub Negroes with you.  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Robinson can't stay here?  HOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the entire team is refused!  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been staying here ten years.  HOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can stay away that long!  SHOTTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (last off the bus)  Hold on now, let's talk about this.  The Hotel Manager jerks his thumb like an umpire.  HOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out! Now, grandpa!  SHOTTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa? Hey hold on, you!  Security getting between as Shotten and the Manager go at

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 96A.
dialogues.text: Jack is embarrassed, but what can he do? Walker says to n one in particular, but loud enough for Jack to hear: WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe 42's got enough friends in town, we can bunk up. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's just, I know when  you can't get into a hotel, you got people's houses you can stay at. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me, Walker? WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An apology.  JACK (STEPS FORWARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? Places like this?  Parrott alarmed at this turn of events.  WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For turning this season into a  sideshow! I'm a ballplayer; I want  to play ball!  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I! I'm here to win!  WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell are we gonna win  sleeping on the bus?!  PARROTT  FELLAS --  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might do you some good the way  you're swinging the bat lately.  DIXIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 97.
dialogues.text: Walker jabs his chest with a finger; Jack bats his hand a JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
