dialogues.text: Watch your damn hand! And they're lunging at each other. Separated by Reese, Stanky, Branca and Bragan while other players hold off Shotton. Two fights about to break out at the same time. SHOTTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa?! I'll show you grandpa! Parrott summons something deep, lets loose a shrill WHIST PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas! Burt! Please! Take the bus to the field! Worry about the game. I'll find another hotel. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Chapman sits across from Herb Pennock who flips throu underlined newspaper reports. Pennock reads one: PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a great lynch mob among us; they go unhooded and work without rope. (looks at him) That's you, not me. (reads some more) We must remember that all this country's enemies are not beyond the frontiers of our home land. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Jew must've wrote that. PENNOCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't look good, Ben! It makes the Phillies, look racist! You've got to do something. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PARROTT. He's trying to work up the nerve for somethin Finally, he comes around the corner where Jack sits at hi locker talking to Smith.  PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, excuse me, um, a request  came in. The Phillies manager Ben Chapman, he'd like his photo taken  with you. Jack pretends to sniff the air around Parrott. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been drinking, Harold? PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey thinks it's a good idea. He says it'll be in every sports page in the country. An example that'll show everyone even the most hardened man can change. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapman hasn't changed. He's just trying to take the heat off. PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rickey says it doesn't matter if he's changed. As long as it looks like he's changed. Chapman  said he'd come down here. Or meet  you in the runway.  As Jack slow burns... SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the ball come in slow. See the  photo come in slower.  JACK  (TO PARROTT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him on the field. Where  everyone can see him. As Parrott smiles; he's done it.  PARROT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapman and Jack stand side-by-side facing the PRESS. Chapman makes a little speech. Hypocrisy at its best. CHAPMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's been accepted in baseball and the Philadelphia organization wish him all the luck we can. I only hope in some small way our trial of fire... helped him along. Jack looks at him: Did he just say that?

dialogues.speaker: GREEN REV 4-27-12 99.
dialogues.text: PHOTOGRAPHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a picture? Shake hands. Bury the hatchet? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a picture? Sure. Jack steps to the on-deck circle, grabs a BASEBALL BAT. Chapman's eyes widen as he starts toward him with it. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low to Chapman) We'll hold the bat. That way we don't have to touch skin. Chapman nods, looks relieved. A photographer hands over a bat. Chapman has two hands on the handle. Jack puts one hand on the barrel, the other stays on his hip. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I hope all your friends back home like the picture. Jack smiles as the flashbulbs go off. Chapman looks dumb. DIXIE WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the dugout with Stanky, watches in disbelief.  WALKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, I swear, I never thought I'd see ol' Ben eat shit like that. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRITZ OSTERMUELLER on the mound. He takes a long look in Jack, at his catcher KLUTTZ who flicks his thumb: âHit INSERT: May 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Here it comes. All Jack has time to do is cover his face lessen the blow. Beaned in the head, he goes down in a he Branca leads the Dodger players out onto the field. The UMPIRES move to head them off. Pirates as well. Kirby Higbe, now in a Pirate uniform, claps his hands pleased. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his face) Ostermeuller, you kraut! You gotta bat, too! Don't you forget! OSTERMUELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready, you Wop bastard!

dialogues.speaker: PINK REV 4-19-12 99A.
dialogues.text: BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna come right between your  eyes! Like a Kamikaze!  OSTERMUELLER  (RE: JACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For him!? He doesn't belong here!  BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't belong here! Go home to  Goering and Shmelling!  OSTERMUELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make me, you goddamn dago!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 100.
dialogues.text: As an UMPIRE gets between them, Jack sits up. He's okay. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey looks up as Reese enters. He holds a LETTER. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Pee Wee? REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Rickey, it's like this, the series in Cincinnati next week. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an important road trip, we're only three games out of first. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You know, I'm from Kentucky. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cincinnati's nearly a home game for you. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got this letter, sir. I guess some people aren't too happy about me playing with Robinson. Rickey is not liking where this is going; he motions for letter, scans it, reads the highlights... RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigger lover. Watch yourself. We will get you, carpetbagger. (holds it out) Typical stuff. Reese takes the letter back, a little hurt. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not typical to me. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of these letters have you gotten, Pee Wee? REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just this. Ain't that enough? Rickey looks Reese over a moment. Pushing back his chair steps over to a filing cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 101.
dialogues.text: Motioning Reese to join him, he pulls open a drawer, pull out a 4-inch stack of flattened letters, then another, th third. He looks to Reese.

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are those? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what they aren't, they aren't letters from the Jackie Robinson fan club. Here -- He thrusts a sheaf of it into Reese's hands. As Reese fli through the stack of hate, reads: REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of baseball, or your baby boy will die. (NEXT ONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit baseball or your Nigger wife will be... Reese trails off, won't say it out loud. Skips to another

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out of the game or be killed. He looks at one more, reacts to the vitriol, but does not utter it. Reese looks back at Rickey, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does Jackie know? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he knows. And the FBI. They're taking a threat in Cincinnati pretty seriously. So excuse me if I'm not too shocked at you being called a carpetbagger. You should be proud of it! REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd just like to play ball, Mr. Rickey. That's all we want to do. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I bet Jackie just wants to play ball. I bet he wishes he wasn't leading the league in hit by pitch. I bet he wishes people didn't want to kill him. But the world isn't so simple anymore. I'm not sure it ever was. We just, baseball ignored it. Now we can't.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 102.
dialogues.text: REESE (QUIET)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. I gotta get to practice. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A 10-YEAR OLD BOY 165 165
dialogues.text: In the stands. Freckled, cute. Looking at the men around him, his own FATHER SHOUTING at Jack as the Dodgers take field (the Reds coming off it).  Jack headed for first. Pee Wee out to short.  FRECKLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigger! (then...) We don't want you here! INSERT: Crosley Field, Cincinnati, June 21, 1947.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Cincinnati fans expressing their displeasure as the Dodgers take the field. Jackie Robinson at first. The Brat Eddie Stanky at second. Spider Jorgensen at third. And the captain Pee Wee Reese at shortstop. (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask any man and they'll tell you that the Gillette Superspeed razor is a honey. Maybe the sweetest shaving razor you'll ever use. 166 OMITTED 166 167 OMITTED 167

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack reaches first, throws the ball around the infield. M in the crowd beyond rise to jeer and heap abuse. COON! SHINE! Jack tries to let it wash over him. At short, Reese receives the ball, moves to throw to firs when he pauses. Deciding, he suddenly moves to trot acros the diamond until he's alongside Jack. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up? Now cries of CARPETBAGGER! cut through. PEE WEE, HOW CAN PLAY WITH THIS BLACK BASTARD!? Reese stares up at the wor hecklers along the first base line. He looks a little sad REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can say what they want; we're here to play baseball. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a bunch of crackpots still fighting the Civil War. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, we'd a won that son of a gun if the cornstalks had held out. We just ran out of ammunition. Jack laughs. Reese has a funny way of saying it. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better luck next time, Pee Wee. Reese impulsively puts his arm around Jack's shoulder, st into the Cincy dugout. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna be a next time. All we got is right now. This right here. Know what I mean? Walker reacting out in right. The crowd shuts down, some shock at the gesture. Jack surprised also.

dialogues.speaker: REESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jackie. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you thanking me for? REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got family here from Louisville. Up there somewhere. I need âem to know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 104.
dialogues.text: Jack moved by Pee Wee's gesture, can't find the words.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Robinson and Reese conferring at  first. Maybe discussing an infield  shift on Baumholtz.  UMPIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Number one! You playing ball or socializing? REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing ball, ump! Playing ball! (TO JACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow we'll all wear 42. That way they won't be able to tell us apart. Reese heads for short. Jack pounds his fist in his glove. CUT TO: 169 OMITTED 169 170 OMITTED 170

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack playing Gin Rummy with Branca, Reese and Wendell Smi BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith; teasing) You ever write about white guys in your paper? I mean, if I threw a no hitter and Jackie got a base hit, what would the headline be? SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie leads Dodgers to victory. Again. Under that: white Italian guy does ok. They all laugh. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call your folks for ya, Ralph. Tell âem how you did. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. It'll still make the Post. They play their hands as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 105.
dialogues.text: REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on some kind of winning streak, huh boys? And I don't mean cards. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe forty of our last fifty. SMITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-two and fifteen actually. Since the 4th of July. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Math is why I throw a baseball for a living. REESE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This next series against the Cardinals, it's a big one. They look over at Jack who hasn't said a word. It's his play. He lays his cards down. Deadpan as he wins the hand JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The top of the 11th inning, all  tied at 2. For those of you just  tuning in, how did we get here?  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A172 JACK AT BAT A172
dialogues.text: Jack strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky breaks second for third.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's been double trouble as  Robinson knocked in Stanky with a  double in the third...

dialogues.speaker: B172 DIXIE WALKER AT BAT B172
dialogues.text: Walker strokes a DOUBLE over Stanky's head as Stanky brea off second for third.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: ...And Dixie Walker did the same  with a double in the eighth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENOS SLAUGHTER steps in for St. Louis. Hugh Casey on the mound for Brooklyn. Slaughter looks fiercely determined.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It wasn't enough as the Cardinals tied it with two of their own in the top of the ninth. This game is crucial to the Red Birds. They're five games out, the Dodgers having not relinquished first place sine June 30th. Casey throws a pitch. Inside, a ball. INSERT: August 20, 1947. Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: RED BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Slaughter takes ball one low. Casey in his second inning of relief. This game is tighter than a new pair of shoes on a rainy day. Slaughter hitless in four trips as  Casey goes into his wind-up.  Slaughter swings, hits a hard ground ball right at Reese fires over to Jack at first. Slaughter is out by fifteen feet, but he never slows down. And his foot comes down -- -- High on Jack's right calf. Slaughter's spiked him something wicked. Jack goes down in a heap clutching his leg, blood already seeping through his high socks. Slaughter, head down, on his way to the visitor's dugout Dodger players pour out of their own to protest. As the U raises his hands, motions them all back... Jack pulls up sock, a bloody mess. Stanky looks to Casey.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE 3-14-12 106.
dialogues.text: STANKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next batter, throw right at his head. Clean his clock -- JACK (FIERCE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get him out. Understand? Game's too important. As Casey nods, Jack reaches up to Stanky and Reese. They pull him to his feet. Jack looks, finds Rachel in th stands. As he gives her a little wave: âI'm okay.' CUT TO: 173 WHITEY KUROWSKI 173

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big Cardinal slugger at bat. Casey pitching. BARBER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top of the 12th and Kurowski at the plate. He hit his 20th home run on Monday so Casey's going to want to be careful with him. The pitch grooves in and Kurowski nails it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh dear. There goes number 21. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: The Cardinals leading 3-2 going into the bottom of the 12 175 JACK 175

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stadium electric as Jack steps in, his left leg blood He takes an inside pitch at the knees. Bastards! Here comes the next one. WHACK - He singles hard up the middle, nearly takes the pitcher's head off. FIRST BASE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rounds hard, returns to the bag. Reiser stepping up to the plate as Musial holds Jack on at first. Jack in a fur JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what happens, I don't care what kind of play it is, when I get to second I'm gonna knock someone into centerfield.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 107.
dialogues.text: MUSIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at blood) I don't blame you, man, you got every right. Jack running on the pitch. Reiser bunts. The play is to first. Reiser is out and Jack slides safe into second. SCHOENDIENST has the sense to vacate before he gets there JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing up and down, wearing that badge of potential violence and action. The crowd buzzing, the electricity practically hits you in the face. Jack's going to score. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up out of his seat along with the fans around him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker at bat. Jack steps out, checks on MARION the shortstop. He takes another step out, looks to Schoendien RED BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over it all)  Munger sets. Robbie back and forth  off second. The third bag clearly  in his sights. Oh, and Munger  deals a pick off throw to Marion at  second and Robinson is out!  Marion breaks for the bag and Munger turns and fires a  strike. Marion brings down the tag -- Out!  He is and he knows it. The crowd stunned into silence. Ja frozen a moment, head down, furious with himself. Low.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The Cardinals pick up a game. It  was one of those plays where you do or you don't and Jackie didn't. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack on his stomach as STITCHES are sewn into his leg. REPORTERS in front of him. REPORTER ONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he spike you on purpose?

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW REV 4-24-12 107A.
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw the play. I had my foot  inside the bag. He was out by a  mile. But he kept coming.  REPORTER TWO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slaughter said it was an accident.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you asking me for then? REPORTER TWO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you calling Slaughter a liar?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY REV 6-11-12 108.
dialogues.text: This guy's a real jerk. Rickey arrives, a BASEBALL in han RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out. Let me talk to my first baseman. Go. He's getting stitched up for Pete's sake. The reporters move off for other interviews. Reporter Two hesitant to let it go, finally drifts off. Rickey watches RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sticking up for yourself is what you'd expect of any man. Some find it galling to see it in a Negro. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Rickey. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? Sorry for what? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my cool out there. It probably cost us the game. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Jackie, all the best base runners get caught sometimes. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinking. Rickey pulls up a chair sits across from him, leans in. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what I saw this morning? I was passing a sandlot and a little white boy was up to bat. You know what he was doing? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on a fastball? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was pretending he was you.  Wiping his hands on his pants,  swinging with his arms outstretched  like you do. A little white boy  pretending he was a black man.  CUT TO: 177 OMITTED 177

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, who have done so much, looking each other ov JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey? RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had victory over fascism in Germany; it's time for victory over racism at home. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? Come on now. A long moment between them. Finally, Rickey looks away. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this game. I love baseball. I've given my life to it. Forty odd years ago I was a player coach at Ohio Wesleyan University. We had a Negro catcher, best hitter on the team. Charley Thomas. Rickey starts slowly rubbing the baseball in his hands. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine young man. I saw him laid low. Broken because of the color of his skin and I didn't do enough to help. I told myself I did, but I didn't. The game I loved had something unfair at the heart of it. I ignored it. But a time came when I could no longer do that. (LOOKS UP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me love baseball again. Thank you. Jack's eyes gentle on Rickey's. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 110.
dialogues.text: Rickey fighting back tears now, retreats to his more  confident self.  RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a force of nature, Jackie, you've complicated everything but yourself. You're changing the world, and refusing to let it change you. I for one am in awe. Jack reaches, takes the baseball from him. A beat as they consider each other. Finally, a promise...  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't get picked off second base again. Not this year. CUT TO: 179 OMITTED 179 180 OMITTED 180 181 OMITTED 181 182 OMITTED 182

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REV 5-9-12 111.
dialogues.text: 183 OMITTED 183

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early. Rachel watches from bed as Jack finishes packing. She looks sad. Jack looks into the cradle at Jackie Jr.. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pop's last long road trip of the year, little man. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful you don't wake him. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I won't. (LOOKS OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like seeing you leave, that's all. He looks at her a beat, resumes packing...  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be home in a week. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven days. That's a long time  without you.  He doesn't answer, packs away. Finally:  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to lunge at the plate.  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they're throwing the fastballs inside. He looks at her, a little shocked.

dialogues.speaker: DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 112.
dialogues.text: RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight those inside fastballs off, foul them back. Sooner or later they won't be able to help but throw a curve. He steps to the bed, leans over her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what'll happen then? She clucks a 'hit' sound, makes an 'ahhhhhh' crowd sound. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We win enough of these next games and we'll bring home the pennant. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pennant? Where are we going to put a pennant? All these baby diapers hanging everywhere. Jack looks around the room, at the diapers hanging. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got room right over there. Between number one and number two. She mock grimaces at his bad joke. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Win one if you have to, but bring yourself home; that'll be plenty. They kiss. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rae, you're in my heart. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you'll come home. That you'll always come home. As he looks at all he loves in the world... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack exits MacDonough Street apartment building and makes way down the street.  185 OMITTED 185

dialogues.speaker: BUFF REV 5-29-12 113-114.
dialogues.text: 186 OMITTED 186 187 OMITTED 187 188 OMITTED 188

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CARDINAL RUNNER on second. Jackie holding another RUNNE on first as the St. Louis crowd ROARS.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: 2 on 2 out for the Cardinals in the  eighth. Anxious moments now as  they've cut the Dodger lead to 2.  Nippy Jones up. Musial taking his  place on deck. Jones likes to  punch that ball when he swings.  Insert: September 13, 1947. Casey on the mound receives the ball. Pounds his glove. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Casey, get him out! Pitch that ball!

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The outfield is deep, shaded toward  left. Robinson holding the runner  on first. Here comes Casey with  the pitch --  Jones swings, pops it up.  BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's popped up foul toward first.  Should be out of play. But here  comes Robinson, he's coming hard --  189 OMITTED 189  190 OMITTED 190  191 OMITTED 191  192 OMITTED 192

dialogues.speaker: BUFF REV 5-29-12 115.
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack chasing down the foul, headed right for the open ste of his own dugout. He never considers the peril as he CATCHES THE BALL and his left foot comes down onto nothin BRANCA LEAPS forward, tackles Jack back onto the infield. BARBER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got it! And one of the Dodgers has him!  CUT TO: 194 OMITTED 194  195 OMITTED 195

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The Dodgers closing in on the  Pennant as they'll leave St. Louis  for Cincinnati and a three game  series with the Reds.  Jack sits in his grass stained pants after the game. Most the guys are in the shower. Branca, a towel around his waist, is headed there himself. The sight of Jack stops h BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something, Jackie? How come you never shower until everyone else is done? Jack just stares at him. Branca won't let it drop. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shy or something? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to make anyone uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: BUFF REV 5-29-12 116.
dialogues.text: BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a team. On a hot streak. Half the wins on account of you. You're the bravest guy I ever saw. You're leading us and you're afraid to take a shower? A beat as Jack considers him. Stone-faced. BRANCA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Take a shower with me. (A BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I don't mean it like that. CUT TO: 197 SHOWERS 197

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dodgers showering, guys chattering. Suddenly, there's Branca and Jack at the shower entrance. All eyes look ove Branca enters. Then Jack. A beat and everyone goes back t getting clean. It's no big deal. Except... Dixie Walker looks to the floor, shakes his head. Finally quietly, he leaves. Who's the loneliest man on the team n CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the phone rings, Rickey grabs it. On edge. INSERT: September 16, 1947 RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rickey here.

dialogues.speaker: PARROTT 199
dialogues.text: On a payphone in the CROSLEY FIELD CONCOURSE. PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it, Boss! We did it! We swept Cincinnati! That puts us  seven games up.  Joyous, Rickey grabs a sheet showing the NL standings. RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eliminates the Giants and  Boston. He puts an âX' through Boston and the Giants. The rest the NL are already crossed out. Only the Cardinals remain At the same time, Parrott X's the same out on his noteboo

dialogues.speaker: DBL. BLUE REV 7-9-12 117.
dialogues.text: RICKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd have to lose nearly every game for the Cardinals to catch us now. One more win may do it. Who's pitching tomorrow for the Pirates? PARROTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ostermueller. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel walks pushing Jackie Junior in his stroller. As sh moves, the RADIO BROADCAST of the Dodgers' game can be he from one house to the next. In a gap, a passing car picks up and we hear it from the window. Then another house.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: A very big game today here in Pittsburgh. A win and the Dodgers will have clinched the National League Pennant. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey alone in the stadium. The field empty as he listens to the call of the game over the PA. BARBER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fritz Ostermueller on the mound. He's 12 and 8 on the season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: September 17, 1947. Pittsburgh. Ostermueller on the rubber. Staring in at Jack. OSTERMUELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't belong! You'll never belong! Jack waits. Ostermueller pitches.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Here comes the pitch and Robinson takes outside. Ball one.

dialogues.speaker: 200A RACHEL
dialogues.text: Listening as --

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ostermueller winds and throws, low and away ball two. Fritz seems to be pitching around Jackie. Or trying to get him to chase. RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Throw him a strike. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakes off one sign, then nods at the next. Throws the ba well outside. Another pitch outside. âBall Three!â

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: 3 and 0 now. Robinson waiting on something he can swing on. As catcher Kluttz throws it back... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me something I can hit! (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? OSTERMUELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it?! (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful what you wish for boy... Ostermueller nods at the sign. Jack about to slay the dra as the pitch comes in - WHACK! The ball is going for a ri

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That is a deep fly ball to left. Kiner on his horse, but I don't think he'll get there.

dialogues.speaker: 200C EBBETS FIELD 200C
dialogues.text: Rickey standing, looking up like he can see it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Back, back, back and oh doctor! Robinson got his pitch! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: 200D FORBES FIELD 200D
dialogues.text: The ball sails out: HOME RUN! Ostermueller hangs his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel listening, smiling as CHEERS sound from outside th apartment. We hear the sound of car horns on the street.

dialogues.speaker: 200F JACK 200F
dialogues.text: He runs toward first and we run with him. The smile start somewhere in his body. His heart most likely. By the time it reaches his face, his joy has erupted. The weight of t world starting to drop.

dialogues.speaker: TAN REV 6-25-12 118.
dialogues.text: 201 PIRATES DUGOUT 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirby Higbe who watches Robinson round the bases in disgu HIGBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh... 202 JACKIE ROBINSON 202

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nears second on his home run trot. Even the Pittsburgh cr starting to applaud him. CUT TO: 203 OMITTED 203

dialogues.speaker: 203A EBBETS FIELD 203A
dialogues.text: Rickey absorbing the moment. It's almost too much.  204 JACKIE ROBINSON 204

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rounding second and headed for third. The weight of the world somehow lifting. They gave him one he could hit. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're tight on Jack's back as he heads for home at Forbes Field. 90 feet away... 75...

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL SMITH IN THE STANDS 207
dialogues.text: Finally inspired to type: T-h-a-n-k y-o-u, J-a-c-k-i-e. 208 JACKIE ROBINSON 208

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearing home. About to step on the plate. He closes his eyes as well and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel all alone on the sidewalk looking up and down the  street. And suddenly there he is... Jack, scooting betwee two cars, hurrying to her. And they're in each others arm JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm home.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safe.  (RE: HOUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby's sleeping so don't you  make a sound.  He makes to button his lips.  RACHEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay just like that.  She kisses him. And kisses him. And he kisses her back. A they finally head inside, we let them go. And as we're le looking down the street, a crawl begins:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE REV 4-07-12 120.
dialogues.text: Branch Rickey was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1967.  Pee Wee Reese was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1984. Bobby Bragan retired the following year and became a mana in the Dodger minor leagues. He is credited with mentorin several African American minor league players. Wendell Smith became the first African-American sportswri to join the Baseball Writers Association in 1948. Ben Chapman was fired in 1948 and never managed again. Eddie Stanky went on to manage the St. Louis Cardinals, t Chicago White Sox and the Texas Rangers.  Ralph Branca lives and works in Rye, New York.  Dixie Walker was traded the following season to Pittsburg Ed Charles grew up to become a professional baseball play He won the World Series in 1969 with the Miracle Mets. Rachel Robinson splits her time between Connecticut and Manhattan where she runs the Jackie Robinson Foundation. Jackie Robinson was named Major League Rookie of the Year 1947. He won the World Series in 1955 against the New Yor Yankees, stealing home in Game One. He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962.  We end on a montage of Jackie Robinson Day in present tim Every year in April, all MLB players wear the number 42 a reminder of Jackie's accomplishments on and off the field The number 42 is the only number retired by all of baseba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see 42s leaving their dugouts, 42s at bat, 42s in the field, 42s signing autographs, 42s stealing bases, 42s li up for the National Anthem. FREEZE FRAME on a 42. The End.
